questions.text:
As the junior resident posted in the casualty, you are making the AR entries for patients presenting with various wounds. Which of the following should you classify as having a grievous injury?
  1. A 22-year-old man with scrotal trauma resulting in emasculation
  2. A 33-year-old lady who has lost hearing in one ear due to a ruptured tympanic membrane which is now showing signs of healing
  3. A 16-year-old girl who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal hemorrhage, but no other facial injuries
  4. A 39-year-old man with the loss of his premolar tooth due to trauma, and a small abrasion on the face
  5. A 12-year-old with a lacerated wound over the cheek, which would heal with a scar even if expertly sutured
questions.solution:
The following would be considered as grievous hurt:

  • A 22-year-old man with scrotal trauma resulting in emasculation
  • A 39-year-old man with the loss of his premolar tooth due to trauma, and a small abrasion on the face
  • A 12-year-old with a lacerated wound over the cheek, which would heal with a scar even if expertly sutured

The 33-year-old lady who has lost hearing in one ear due to a ruptured tympanic membrane which is now showing signs of healing and the 16-year-old girl who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal hemorrhage, but no other facial injuries have only suffered temporary privation/partial loss of function - hence would not be considered as grievous.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily on another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Grievous hurt is a cognizable offence for which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from a magistrate (Section 320 IPC).

Punishment for grievous hurt :

  • Section 325, IPC Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
  • Section 326, IPC Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding superior orbital fissure?

choices.text: Lacrimal nerve and Frontal nerve pass above the common tendinous ring
Superior division of oculomotor nerve passes above the common tendinous ring while the inferior division  passes below it.
Abducens nerve and Nasociliary nerve pass within the common tendinous ring
Inferior ophthalmic vein passes below the common tendinous ring

questions.solution:
Both divisions of the oculomotor nerve pass within the common tendinous ring.

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring.

Compartments

Contents

Superolateral compartments

Lacrimal, frontal and trochlear nerve (LFT). Superior ophthalmic vein

Intermediate compartment

Superior and inferior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary nerve, Abducent nerve

Inferomedial compartment

Inferior ophthalmic vein

 

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be associated with Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus, is associated with Turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females.

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

Image showing the features of Turner syndrome:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a phosphonic acid derivative that is used primarily for the prevention and treatment of UTIs?
questions.solution:
Fosfomycin acts by inhibition of MurA, an enolpyruvyl transferase that catalyzes the initial step in bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is a phosphonic acid derivative and is used in the prevention and treatment of UTIs.

Fosfomycin:

  • Inhibits early cell wall synthesis
  • Excellent activity vs. E. coli, Proteus, Enterococcus
  • Some activity vs. Klebsiella, Enterobacter
  • Single-dose treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis

questions.text: Which of the following relations of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Roof - Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum
Anteriorly - Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
Medial wall - Forceps major and calcar avis

questions.solution:
Medial wall of posterior horn is formed by forceps major and calcar avis. The medial wall of the anterior horn is formed by septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

The lateral ventricle is divided into the body and 3 horns. The locations of the parts are: 

  • Body - parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn - frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn - occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn - temporal lobe.

 

 

The anterior horn extends from the genu of the corpus callosum up to the interventricular foramen. The relations of the anterior horn are: 

  • Anteriorly - Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof - Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 
  • Floor and lateral wall - Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall - Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

The body or central part extends from the interventricular foramen to the splenium of the corpus callosum. The relations of the body are: 

  • Roof - Body of the corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Septum pellucidum 
  • Floor (from lateral to medial) - Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

The posterior horn extends from the splenium to the occipital pole. The relations are: 

  • Roof and lateral wall - Tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

The inferior horn is the largest compartment of the lateral ventricle and extends up to 2.5 cm from the temporal pole. The relations are: 

  • Roof - Tapetum of corpus callosum and tail of caudate nucleus
  • Floor (lateral to medial) - Collateral eminence produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus.

Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text:
Arrange the following blood products according to the storage duration from lowest to highest.
  1. RBCs in ACD/ CPD
  2. RBCs in CPD-A
  3. Platelets
  4. Fresh frozen plasma
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 3<1<2<4.

The recommended storage periods for different blood components are as follows:

RBCs in ACD/ CPD - 21 Days
RBCs in CPD-A - 35 Days
Platelets - 5 Days
Fresh frozen plasma - 1 year

questions.text: You would advise a Skyline view Xray for a patient with suspected:
questions.solution:
Skyline view is used for visualization of patella fractures.

Patellar fractures are classified as:

  • Transverse
  • Vertical
  • Polar
  • Comminuted fractures

These fractures may be either undisplaced or displaced.

The tendon of the quadriceps muscle is attached to the upper surface of the patella. These fractures are usually caused by the excessive pull of the quadriceps muscle, either due to excessive contractions or sudden resisted extension of the knee.

X-ray of a normal patella in skyline view:

 

  • Judet view is used for Acetabulum
  • Mortise view is used in Talus fractures
  • Stryker notch view is useful for Hillsach's lesion

Related Pearl: Common X-Ray views

questions.text: All of the following inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, except ______.
questions.solution:
Lugol’s iodine does not inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli is best perceived by Ruffini corpuscles?

choices.text: Point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter

questions.solution:
Ruffini corpuscles detect stretch and joint rotation. Ruffini corpuscles are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly adapting receptors. The image below shows a Ruffini corpuscle.

Meissner's corpuscles are present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is well developed. They have small receptive fields which help in two­ point discrimination. Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that sense point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter. These are encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve (Aβ type). The image shows the histology of Meissner's corpuscle in the dermis.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers. The image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Merkel discs are seen in the epidermis of glabrous skin. They are slowly adapting receptors and have very small receptive fields. These receptors detect vertical indentations of the skin. They are expanded dendritic endings. The image below shows a Merkel disc.

Pain and temperature sensations arise from receptors located on unmyelinated sensory neurons present throughout the glabrous skin, hairy skin, and deep tissue. Impulses from nociceptors are transmitted via thinly myelinated Aδ fibres and unmyelinated C fibres.

Activation of Aδ fibres is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain). It is a rapid response and helps in the discrimination of pain or the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus. It is mediated by the release of glutamate. An example is a pinprick.

Activation of C fibres is responsible for delayed second pain (also called slow pain). It is a dull, intense, diffuse, and unpleasant feeling associated with a noxious stimulus. Second pain is mediated by the release of a combination of glutamate and substance P. Example is visceral pain.

Types of nociceptors :

  • Mechanical nociceptors respond to strong pressure (eg, from a sharp object). 
  • Thermal nociceptors are activated by skin temperatures above 45°C or by severe cold (<20°C).
  • Chemically sensitive nociceptors respond to chemicals such as bradykinin, histamine, high acidity, and environmental irritants.
  • Polymodal nociceptors respond to combinations of these stimuli.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: Which of the following positions is best suited for surgeries of the posterior cranial fossa?
questions.solution:
Fowler's position or sitting position is best suited for posterior cranial fossa surgery. 

It is associated with a high risk of air embolism.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A patient with type I diabetes requires long-acting insulin for basal cover, but cannot afford an insulin pump. Which of the following preparations is least suited to be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Insulin lispro is a short-acting insulin and hence, cannot be used for basal cover.

Panel A shows the administration of long-acting insulin glargine (green curve) to provide basal insulin and a premeal short-acting insulin analog (red curve) like insulin lispro.

Panel B shows a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin providing basal insulin (yellow curve) and regular insulin (dotted curve) or insulin analog (red curve) providing mealtime insulin coverage. Note that only one type of short-acting insulin would be used.

Yellow curve NPH insulin
Red curve Insulin lispro  
Green curve Insulin glargine  
Dotted blue curve Regular insulin

 

 

The insulin level attained following subcutaneous insulin (short-acting insulin analog) by an insulin pump programmed to deliver different basal rates would appear as below:

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: What is the function of acid alcohol that is used in the Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast staining technique?
questions.solution:
3.0% acid-alcohol (95% ethanol and 3.0% hydrochloric acid) is used for decolorizing.  

Steps involved in the Ziehl-Neelsen stain:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain, staining gently for 5 minutes over direct flame.
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolorized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.


The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for the demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent parts of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • At least 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

Grading of ZN- stained smears for AFB:-

Number of AFB per oil immersion field Grading Number of fields Result
>10 / field 3+ 20 Positive
1-10 / field 2+ 50 Positive
10-99 / 100 field 1+ 100 Positive
1-9 / 100 field Scanty 100 Positive
Nil AFB / 100 field   1000 Negative

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies

Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

questions.text: Weakness and drooping of the shoulder would be seen in a patient who has undergone ______.
questions.solution:
Weakness and drooping of the shoulder indicate trapezius muscle paralysis which occurs due to accessory nerve excision in radical neck dissection.

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of:

  • All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally.
  • All lymph nodes from Levels I through to V
  • The spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Tail of parotid
  • Submandibular gland

A radical neck dissection does not include the removal of the following.

  • sub-occipital nodes
  • peri-parotid nodes (except infraparotid nodes located in the posterior aspect of the submandibular triangle)
  • buccinator nodes
  • retropharyngeal nodes
  • midline visceral (anterior compartment) nodes

There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND). Structures preserved are:

  • MRND 1 - Only spinal accessory nerve 
  • MRND 2 - Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
  • MRND 3 i.e., functional neck dissection - Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins. 

Related Pearl: Types of Neck Dissections

Dissection LN removed Other structures removed/preserved
RND l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed
MRND l l-V CNXI preserved
MRND ll l-V CNXI, IJV preserved
MRND lll l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM preserved
END l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed+ one/more LN groups +/- non-lymphatic structures

 

SND LN removed Primary site of cancer
Supra-omohyoid l-lll Oral cavity
Extended supra-omohyoid l-lV Oral cavity and oropharynx
Postero-lateral

ll-V

Skin over posterior scalp and upper neck
Lateral ll-lV

Oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx
Anterior(Central) Vl Thyroid/midline structures

RND- Radical Neck Dissection; MRND- Modified Radical Neck Dissection; END- Extended Neck Dissection; SND- Selective Neck Dissection

questions.text:
Arrange in descending order of plasma glucose value, at which the following events occur.

 

  1. Inhibition of insulin secretion
  2. Cortisol secretion
  3. Glucagon, epinephrine, growth hormone secretion
  4. Lethargy
  5. Cognitive dysfunction
questions.solution:
The descending order of plasma glucose value, at which the following events occur is:

  • Inhibition of insulin secretion
  • Glucagon, epinephrine, growth hormone secretion
  • Cortisol secretion
  • Cognitive dysfunction 
  • Lethargy

Insulin secretion is completely inhibited at a plasma glucose level of about 80 mg/dL. Below 75 mg/dL, glucagon, epinephrine, and growth hormone secretion occur. Below 60 mg/dL, cortisol secretion follows which is followed by cognitive dysfunction on further decline of plasma sugar levels. Lethargy sets in at plasma sugar levels below 45 mg/dL, which is followed by coma, convulsions, permanent brain damage, and death.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient comes with a history of blunt abdominal trauma and significant intra-abdominal injury is suspected. On performing  eFAST, it is found to be unremarkable. His vitals appear stable. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Perform a full USG abdomen and pelvis once the patient gets a full bladder
Refer the patient to General Medicine care as FAST is a definitive test to rule out intra-abdominal injuries

questions.solution:
Patients with suspected significant intra-abdominal injury but a negative eFAST should be evaluated with a sensitive imaging modality such as CT. FAST is not a definitive test to rule out intraabdominal injuries because of the limited sensitivity of ultrasound.

Many injuries are not detectable by ultrasound. This includes:

  • Diaphragmatic tears
  • Pancreatic lesions
  • Bowel perforations
  • Mesenteric trauma
  • Abdominal injuries that produce <200 mL of free fluid
  • Renal and other retroperitoneal injuries

Also, USG cannot distinguish between urine from blood further contributing to its lower sensitivity and specificity in major pelvic trauma.The sensitivity of eFAST for detecting solid organ injuries is much lower.

FAST stands for Focused assessment with sonography for trauma. It is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Patient in the supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer
  • The following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

The sequential order of FAST is - pericardial sac, the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ), Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ), and pelvis.

4 ‘Ps’ are evaluated in sequence: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

questions.text: Echopraxia is a symptom that is seen in catatonic patients, where the patient typically _______________

choices.text: Mimics the action of other person
Mimics the speech of other person
Makes odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions
Makes no response to instructions or external stimuli

questions.solution:
Mimicking the action of another person is known as echopraxia. 

Catatonia is mostly seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses, including schizophrenia

The features of catatonia are:

  1. Mutism: Complete absence of speech
  2. Rigidity: Maintenance of a rigid posture against efforts to be moved
  3. Negativism: An apparently motiveless resistance to all commands and attempts to be moved, or doing just the opposite.
  4. Posturing: Voluntary assumption of an inappropriate and often bizarre posture for long periods of time
  5. Stupor: Akinesis (no movement) with mutism but with evidence of relative preservation of conscious awareness
  6. Echolalia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of phrases or words heard
  7. Echopraxia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of actions observed
  8. Waxy flexibility: Parts of the body can be placed in positions that will be maintained for long periods of time, even if very uncomfortable; flexible like wax.
  9. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, conflicting impulses and tentative actions are made, but no goal-directed action occurs, e.g. on asking to take out the tongue, the tongue is slightly protruded but taken back again.
  10. Other signs such as mannerisms, stereotypes (verbal and behavioural), automatic obedience (commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature) and verbigeration (incomprehensible speech).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding naloxone?

choices.text: It is a noncompetitive opioid antagonist
It is a pan antagonist with affinity for all known opioid receptors
Fetal and maternal respiratory depression induced by meperidine can be treated with naloxone
Naloxone stimulates the release of prolactin in women

questions.solution:
Naloxone is a competitive pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects of an opioid overdose except sedation.

 

It is a pan antagonist with an affinity for all known opioid receptors. It stimulates the release of prolactin in women. Fetal and maternal respiratory depression induced by meperidine can be treated with naloxone. Tonic-clonic seizures, which at times are seen as part of meperidine and tramadol toxicity, are relieved by treatment with naloxone.

It is important to note that the duration of action of the available antagonists is shorter than that of many opioids. Hence, re-narcotization may occur and the patients may slip back into a coma. So, it is better to consider a continuous infusion of naloxone in such cases.

Interesting combination products include Naloxone-oxycodone fixed-dose combination for opioid-induced constipation in adults, buprenorphine-naloxone combination to prevent intravenous abuse of oral preparation of buprenorphine, etc.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding ankylosing spondylitis?

choices.text: Restricted chest wall motion causes decreased vital capacity
It is associated with HLA DR4
Sacroilitis is often a late manifestation
Most common serious complication of spine is dislocation

questions.solution:
Restricted chest wall motion causes decreased vital capacity in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, but, the ventilatory function is maintained. 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker (about 85 percent), not HLADR4. Sacroilitis is an early manifestation, not late. 

ASAS Categorization Criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients under 45 years of age with lower back pain of 3 months duration:

Criteria comprise 2 sections: one ‘‘radiological section’’ and one ‘‘clinical section’’.

  • To qualify for the radiological section a sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI and at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis needs to be confirmed.
  • To qualify for the clinical section the patient needs to have a positive HLA B27 and at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis being mandatory

Radiological diagnosis of sacroiliitis 
      - Active (acute) inflammation in the MRI is highly suggestive of sacroiliitis due to spondyloarthritis 
      - Radiological sacroiliitis is defined according to the New York criteria (grade >2 bilateral or grade 3 - 4 unilateral)

Features of spondyloarthritis

  • Low inflammatory pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis
  • Uveítis
  • Dactylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn/colitis
  • Good response to NSAID
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA B27
  • High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

Extra-articular involvements are seen as the disease progresses.

  • Ocular - The most common extra-articular manifestation is anterior uveitis, typically unilateral and recurs often
  • Pulmonary - Fibrosis of the upper lobe of the lungs
  • Cardiac - Acute aortic insufficiency, heart blocks
  • Gastrointestinal - inflammation of the ileum or colon
  • Dermatological - Psoriasis
  • Renal - Secondary IgA nephropathy
  • Peripheral joint involvement - shoulder and hips (presence indicates poor prognosis)

Complications that are likely to be seen due to this disease are -

  • Most common serious complication is spinal fracture. Lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture
  • Loss of lumbar curvature (lumbar lordosis) causing limitation of movements in all directions
  • Gluteal muscle atrophy
  • Forward bending (khyphosis) of the thoracic spine leading to reduced chest movements and shallow breathing

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Which of the following is false about histoplasmosis?

choices.text: In histoplasmosis, skin tests are less specific than serological methods
Spores have a characteristic tuberculate appearance
Pulmonary disease due to classical histoplasmosis resembles tuberculosis
African histoplasmosis involves the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones predominantly.

questions.solution:
In histoplasmosis, skin tests are more specific than serological methods.

Delayed type hypersensitivity develops following infection, which is demonstrated by histoplasmin skin testing. It is analogous to the tuberculin test for tuberculosis. 

Person-to-person transmission or animal-to-man transmission is not yet known in the case of histoplasmosis. Transmission is mainly via inhalation of spores. Spores in bird or bat droppings contaminate the soil which acts as a reservoir of infection. Histoplasma capsulatum var. capsulatum, which causes the classical, ubiquitous form of histoplasmosis is endemic in the USA. It has specific geographical distribution. Histoplasma capsulatum var. duboisii causes African histoplasmosis.

Classical histoplasmosis is mostly asymptomatic and heals spontaneously, leaving behind an area of miliary calcification. Some may develop a pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. Disseminated infection of the reticuloendothelial system is highly fatal and manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia. Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions may develop on the skin and mucous membranes. 

African histoplasmosis involves the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones predominantly. The lungs are rarely affected. Disseminated disease is also infrequent.

Histoplasma is a thermally dimorphic fungus - yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37 °C and mycelial form occurs in the soil at 25 °C. At room temperature, white, cottony, mycelial growth appears, with large (8-20 μ) thick-walled, spherical spores with tubercles (finger-like projections called tuberculate spores).

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect with respect to the nature of the bond seen in DNA double helix?

choices.text: Van der Waals forces -Between the stacked adjacent base pairs
Covalent bond - Between the nitrogenous base and deoxyribose sugar
Hydrophobic bond -  Between two phosphate groups
Ester bond - Between sugar and phosphate group of the same nucleotide

questions.solution:
An acid anhydride bond is present between two phosphate groups.

Van der Waals and hydrophobic interactions are present between the stacked adjacent base pairs.

A β-N-glycosidic bond is present between the nitrogenous base and deoxyribose sugar. C1 of deoxyribose/ribose sugar is joined covalently to N1 of pyrimidines and N9 of purines by β-N-glycosidic bond.

An ester bond is present between the sugar and phosphate group of the same nucleotide. A polymer of nucleotides is joined by 3’-5’ phosphodiester bond. The bond is present between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate group of another.

Adenine and thymine are linked by two hydrogen bonds (A=T) whereas three hydrogen bonds are present between cytosine and guanine (C≡G).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding steady-state concentrations?
questions.solution:
Steady-state concentration is directly proportional to the dose of the drug. It is the time to steady state which is independent of dosage.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum. The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is completely eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

A graph is plotted between plasma drug concentration and time as shown below. The given graph depicts the plateau principle of drug accumulation on repeated oral dosing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking amlodipine for the past 3 months. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely to be responsible?

choices.text: Decreased hydrostatic pressure in the lower extremities
Precapillary dilation and reflex post capillary constriction
Precapillary constriction and reflex post capillary dilation

questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema. CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

The frequency of CCB-induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position
  • Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication

Initial treatment of choice 

Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with coronary artery disease

ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D)

Hypertension with chronic kidney disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction

ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B)

Pregnancy

Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

questions.text: While starting a patient on vigabatrin, you counsel him regarding the potential side effects. Which of the following is a side effect associated with it?

choices.text: Progressive and permanent bilateral concentric visual field constriction
Reversible dose dependent visual field constriction

questions.solution:
The given patient has developed a contraction of the visual field, which is a side effect of vigabatrin.

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

questions.text: When asked to give the Sims curette, you would pick:
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

Dilatation and curettage:

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sims speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sims curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette


The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding WHO strategy for control of soil-transmitted helminth infection?

choices.text: The recommended medicines are - albendazole (400 mg) and mebendazole (500 mg).
Treatment should be given thrice a year when prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth infection in the community is over 50 percent.
Treatment should be given once a year when prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth infection in the community is over 20 percent.
WHO recommends periodic deworming without previous individual diagnosis to all at-risk people living in endemic areas.

questions.solution:
Treatment should be given twice a year when the prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth infection in the community is over 50 percent. 

The WHO strategy for control of soil-transmitted helminth infection is to use periodic treatment of at-risk people living in endemic areas to control morbidity. The people at risk are :

  • pre-school-aged children
  • school-aged children
  • women of childbearing age including pregnant women in second and third trimesters and breastfeeding mothers
  • adults in certain high-risk occupations, such as tea-pickers or miners

WHO recommends periodic deworming without a previous individual diagnosis for all at-risk people living in endemic areas. Treatment should be given once a year when the prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth infection in the community is over 20 percent and twice a year if the prevalence is over 50 percent. This reduces the worm burden. The recommended medicines are albendazole (400 mg) and mebendazole (500 mg) and the drugs are donated by WHO.

questions.text: Transesophageal echocardiography would be absolutely contraindicated in patients with all of the following conditions, except ______.
questions.solution:
Recent upper GI bleed is a relative contraindication to Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), not an absolute contraindication. However, in the case of active esophageal varices, TEE is absolutely contraindicated.

TEE is a minimally invasive procedure and could be associated with serious complications like esophageal rupture and mediastinitis in the presence of esophageal injury or disease. In the absence of esophageal disease, the risk is low. 

Absolute contraindications for TEE are:

  • Viscus perforation
  • Esophageal stricture/ tumor/ perforation/ laceration
  • Esophageal diverticulum
  • Active upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed

Relative contraindications for TEE are:

  • Uncooperative patient/ Altered mentation
  • Past history of head, neck, or mediastinum radiation
  • Recent upper GI bleed
  • History of Barrett's esophagus
  • Esophageal varices
  • Active esophagitis
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • Symptomatic hiatal hernia
  • Atlantoaxial joint disease 
  • Severe thrombocytopenia (less than 50k),
  • Elevated international normalized ratio (greater than 4)
  • Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (>150 seconds).

questions.text:
Which of the following are true statements regarding the 20-minute whole blood clotting test?
  1. 2 ml of freshly sampled arterial blood is used
  2. 20 WBCT reporting should be recorded in the case sheets in the form of positive/ negative
  3. In case of neurotoxic envenomation repeat the clotting test after 6 hours
  4. If clotted, the test should be carried out every 1 hour from admission for three hours and then 6 hourly for 24 hours
  5. In case the test is non-clotting, repeat 6 hours after administration of loading dose of ASV
questions.solution:
The true statements are 

  • 2 ml of freshly sampled venous blood is used
  • 20 WBCT reporting should be recorded in the case sheets in the form of clotted/ not clotted
  • In case of neurotoxic envenomation repeat the clotting test after 6 hours.
  • If clotted, the test should be carried out every 1 h from admission for three hours and then 6 hourly for 24 hours.
  • In case the test is non-clotting, repeat 6 hours after administration of loading dose of ASV 

20-minute whole blood clotting test (20 WBCT) is a bedside test to detect vasculotoxic envenomation. To perform this 2-3 ml of freshly sampled venous blood is left undisturbed in a small glass test tube for 20 minutes at ambient temperature.
The test tube is tilted to see if the blood is still liquid. If yes, it would imply the patient has hypofibrinogenaemia as a result of venom-induced consumption coagulopathy. If blood clot is formed and signs and symptoms of neurotoxic envenomation are present, classify it as neurotoxic envenomation. If there is any doubt, the test is repeated in duplicate, including a control blood sample from a healthy person.

It is important to note that if the test tube used for the test is not made of ordinary glass, or if it has been used before and cleaned with detergent, its wall may not stimulate clotting of the blood sample in the usual way and the test will be invalid. It is essential to counsel the patient and the relatives in the beginning that 20 WBCT may be repeated several times before giving any medication.

Repeating the test:

  • If clotted, the test should be carried out every 1 hour from admission for three hours and then 6 hourly for 24 hours.
  • In case test is non-clotting, repeat 6 hours after administration of loading dose of ASV.
  • In case of neurotoxic envenomation repeat clotting test after 6 hours.

 Report of 20WBCT should always be recorded as clotted or not clotted. It should never be recorded as positive/negative to avoid unnecessary confusion.

questions.text:
Match the following fungi with their respective characteristic morphological appearance
  1. Paracoccidioidomycosis
  2. Candidiasis
  3. Cryptococcosis
  4. Chromoblastomycosis
  1. Budding yeasts 
  2. Yeasts with capsules 
  3. Yeasts and Pseudohyphae 
  4. Sclerotic cells
questions.solution:
Key Fungal Structures Observed in Microscopic Examinations of Clinical Specimens

  • Budding yeasts - Blastomycosis, Histoplasmosis, Paracoccidioidomycosis, Penicilliosis, Sporotrichosis
  • Yeasts with capsules - Cryptococcosis
  • Hyphae - septate Hyalohyphomycosis - species of Aspergillus, Fusarium, Geotrichum, Trichosporon, etc
  • Hyphae - septate in skin or nail specimens - Dermatophytosis
  • Hyphae - nonseptate - Mucormycosis - species of Rhizopus, Lichtheimia, Cunninghamella, etc
  • Hyphae - septate; brownish cell walls - Phaeohyphomycosis - species of Bipolaris, Cladosporium, Curvularia, Exserohilum, et al.
  • Yeasts and Pseudohyphae - Candidiasis - species of Candida
  • Yeasts and Hyphae in skin scrapings - Pityriasis versicolor Spherules Coccidioidomycosis
  • Sclerotic cells - brownish cell walls - Chromoblastomycosis
  • Sulfur granules - Mycetoma
  • Arthroconidia in hair - Dermatophytosis
  • Conidia in pulmonary cavity Hyalohyphomycosis - species of Aspergillus, Fusarium, etc
  • Cysts (asci) in pulmonary specimens - Pneumocystis

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding glycopyrrolate, except that ____.

choices.text: Concomitant use with ketamine is contraindicated
It does not cross the blood brain barrier
It is a potent inhibitor of salivary secretions
It is often used in combination with neostigmine

questions.solution:
Glycopyrrolate is indicated in combination with ketamine because of its antisialagogue action. The action of glycopyrrolate helps counteract the increased salivation that is typically associated with ketamine. 

Glycopyrrolate is a quaternary amine compound and lipid insoluble. Therefore, glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Hence, it does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome.

Non-depolarising skeletal muscle relaxants are used in anesthesia. Neostigmine along with glycopyrrolate is used for the reversal of this neuromuscular block. Glycopyrrolate blocks the peripheral muscarinic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine levels after the administration of neostigmine, without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.

Ketamine, whenever used for sedation, is combined with premedication with a barbiturate or benzodiazepine (to reduce the dose requirement of ketamine) and an antisialagogue like glycopyrrolate (to reduce secretions).

questions.text: Cell replication process in which one daughter cell enters a differentiation pathway and gives rise to mature cells, while the other remains undifferentiated and retains its self-renewal capacity is known as _____.
questions.solution:
The cell replication process in which one daughter cell enters a differentiation pathway and gives rise to mature cells, while the other remains undifferentiated and retains its self-renewal capacity is known as asymmetric division.

Symmetric division refers to the process of cell division where both daughter cells retain self-renewal capacity.

In induced Pluripotent Stem (iPS) cells, the genes that confer stem cell properties are introduced into a patient’s differentiated cells. This gives rise to stem cells that can be induced to differentiate into various lineages.

Related Pearl: Classification of Stem Cells

Types of stem cells

Capacity to differentiate

Examples

Totipotent cells

They can form embryonic and extraembryonic cells

Zygote, early blastomeres

Pluripotent cells

They can form all cell types of an embryonic body but cannot form that of the placenta and umbilical cord

Inner cell mass

Multipotent cells

They form more than one category of cells

Hematopoietic stem cells

Oligopotent cells

They form only one category of cells

Vascular stem cells

Unipotent

They can form only one type of cell

Liver cell

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding avascular necrosis of the femur are correct?
  1. X-Ray changes are a result of reactive new bone formation and trabecular failure in the necrotic segment
  2. A Crescent sign on an X-Ray is the result of a fracture
  3. MRI is the most reliable way of diagnosing marrow changes & bone ischemia
  4. Clinical manifestation is late and is usually associated with complaints of pain
  5. Plain X-Ray is highly reliable in the early stages of the disease
questions.solution:
The early signs of ischemia are within the bone marrow and are not seen in the plain X-ray. X-ray changes rarely appear before 3 months after the onset of ischemia. 

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition as a result of diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies.  The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of movements is also a feature of this condition.

The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. 

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis and total or partial replacement are preferred.  

 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: What is the nature of the scotoma that you would expect to see in a patient after the correction of aphakia using spectacles?

choices.text: Scotoma is not associated with spectacle correction of aphakia

questions.solution:
Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens.

 

The position of this scotoma is not fixed in the visual field because the eye keeps moving (or roving) in relation to the aphakic spectacle. Hence, this is called a roving ring scotoma.

This scotoma occurs because the edge of a convex lens acts as a prism. The light falling on the edge of the lens bends (directly proportional to prism angle) towards the base of the prism which is the center of the lens, but doesnot enter the pupil and is therefore seen as nothing (scotoma). The greater the angle the more will be the bending and subsequently larger the scotoma. This results in a ring-shaped scotoma is more prominent in aphakic spectacles because of the large angle of bending. Other difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following:

  • Image magnification by 25–30%
  • Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect”
  • Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens
  • Reduced visual fields
  • Physical inconvenience

For aphakia: Best correction is obtained by an intraocular lens (IOL).

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following would not be a contraindication for eye donation?

choices.text: Patient with Tetanus at the time of death
Patient with Parkinson's disease at the time of death
Patient on ventilator for about 24 hours before death
Patient with malaria at the time of death

questions.solution:
Patient on ventilator for >72 hours before death is a contraindication for eye donation, not 24 hours. 

The contraindications for eye call/ retrieval are:

  • Systemic Infections 
    • HIV/AIDS
    • Hepatitis B & C
    • Syphilis
    • Rabies
    • Septicemia
    • Tetanus
    • Viral diseases like dengue etc
    • Malaria
    • Miliary TB
  • Local Infections of the Eye
    • Conjunctivitis
    • Pus discharge from the eye
    • Corneal ulcer
  • Malignancies
    • Leukemia
    • Lymphoma
    • Retinoblastoma
    • Malignant melanoma of the eye
    • Metastatic tumor in the eye
  • Neurological disease
    • Alzheimer's disease
    • Dementia
    • Parkinson's
    • Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease
    • Unknown neurological disorders
  • Other conditions
    • Patient on a ventilator for >72 hours 
    • Cyanide poisoning
    • Congenital rubella syndrome
    • Reye's syndrome
    • Death due to unknown causes

questions.text:
Which of the following situations would preclude alteplase administration to a patient with the following CT finding?
  1. Presentation at 2 hours of symptom onset
  2. A platelet count of 180,000/ µL
  3. Sustained BP of 200/112 mmHg
  4. History of gastrointestinal bleeding about a week ago
  5. History of head injury 2 years prior
questions.solution:
The image shows a thrombus in the middle cerebral artery, indicating an ischemic stroke. A sustained blood pressure >185/110 mmHg and GI bleeding in the preceding 21 days are contraindications for initiating thrombolysis in ischemic stroke.

 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: All of the following modalities are mass approaches for communication, except _______.
questions.solution:
Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it. It is a group approach of communication.

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Role play
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: Which of the following steps in collagen synthesis occurs intracellularly?

choices.text: Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
Intra- and interchain cross-links formation via Schiff bases and aldol condensation products

questions.solution:
Triple helix formation occurs intracellularly.

Intracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Signal peptide cleavage
  • Hydroxylation of prolyl residues and some lysyl residues, glycosylation of some hydroxylysyl residues
  • Intrachain and interchain S–S bonds formation in extension peptides
  • Triple helix formation

Extracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Amino- and carboxyl-terminal propeptides cleavage
  • Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
  • Oxidative deamination of h -amino groups of lysyl and hydroxylysyl residues to aldehydes
  • Intra- and interchain cross-links formation via Schiff bases and aldol condensation products

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: On performing a swinging flashlight test, the following finding is noted. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows Marcus Gunn pupil/ relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. Iridoplegia refers to paralysis of the iris sphincter. It would result in the pupil not responding to both ipsilateral and contralateral stimulus, not just the ipsilateral one, as seen in RAPD.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease. It also occurs in severe retinal disease. 

The following image shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other specific Pupillary signs:

Argyll Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus. When light is shone on the pupils, they do not react. However, they contract on convergence. 

The tonic pupil of Adie is a dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. The affected pupil is dilated. When light is shone on the pupil, constriction is present but is of low magnitude. It has sluggish reaction to convergenece.

An absolute afferent pupillary defect (amaurotic pupil) is caused by a complete optic nerve lesion where the involved eye is completely blind. When light is shone on the affected eye, neither pupil constricts. When light is shone on the normal eye, both pupils constrict.

questions.text: Which of the following items is least suited for disposal in a landfill?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the urinary bag, which is a plastic waste is the least suitable for disposal in a landfill. 

Plastic wastes such as urinary bags are disposed of in the red bin and should not be sent to landfill. Plastic waste can be sent for diesel, fuel oil and road making.

Waste sharps including metals can be disposed of by autoclaving or dry heat sterilisation ---> shredding/ mutilation/ encapsulation in metal containers or cement concrete ---> final disposal in a sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit or be sent to approved iron foundries.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation
