 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A gluten-free diet in a patient with celiac disease would result in _____.

choices.text: Prompt clinical, histological and serological response, with antibodies disappearing completely
Prompt clinical, and serological response, with antibodies disappearing completely  but persistent histological changes
Prompt clinical, and histological response, with antibodies present at stable titer  levels
Prompt clinical response but both histological and serological picture remaining stable/ unaltered

questions.solution:
A gluten-free diet in a patient with celiac disease would result in prompt clinical, histological and serological response, with antibodies disappearing completely.

Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome secondary to the introduction of gluten in the diet.

It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. 

Histology shows a flat appearance of the intestine with crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes, and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria.

The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.

questions.text: Which of the following appearance of Bacillus anthracis is incorrectly paired with the modality in which it is seen?

choices.text: Bamboo stick appearance on gram staining from cultures
String of pearls reaction in Elek's gel
Medusa head appearance of colony in nutrient agar
Inverted fir tree appearance in gelatin stab culture

questions.solution:
A string of pearls reaction of Bacillus anthracis is seen in a solid medium containing penicillin- 0.05-0.50 units/ml.

B.anthracis grown in this medium for 3-6 hours become large and spherical, and occur in chains on the surface of the agar, resembling a string of pearls. String of pearls reaction on solid media containing penicillin.


Appearances of Bacillus anthracis:

  • Boxcar appearance/bamboo stick appearance on gram stain from culture
  • Medusa head appearance of the colony in nutrient agar
  • M’Fadyean’s reaction – It shows a capsule when stained with polychrome methylene blue.
  • Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab
  • Frosted glass appearance on the agar plate

questions.text: Which of the following agents may be prescribed for the treatment of the following lesion?
questions.solution:
The above image shows small, closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base which are suggestive of herpes simplex. It is best treated with oral acyclovir.

It is commonly caused by herpes simplex virus type 1(HSV-1) and rarely by herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2). It begins with a prodrome of pain, burning, and tingling followed by the appearance of erythematous papules. The papules then become vesicular and may ulcerate.

questions.text:
Match the following gaits with the respective disorders in which they are typically seen.
  1. Circumduction gait
  2. Trendelenburg gait
  3. Quadriceps gait
  4. High-stepping gait
  1. Sciatic Nerve Injury
  2. Hemiplegia
  3. Gluteus medius paralysis
  4. Polio
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. Circumduction gait - Hemiplegia
  2. Trendelenburg gait - Gluteus medius paralysis
  3. Quadriceps gait - Polio
  4. High-stepping gait - Sciatic Nerve Injury 

High-stepping gait is a gait abnormality seen with foot drop due to injury to the sciatic nerve. A high stepping gait helps to clear the dropped foot off the ground while walking due to problems with dorsiflexion. Temporary measures to relieve the foot drop involve physiotherapy and toe raising spring. Posterior tibialis transfer is indicated in complete foot drop.

Circumduction gait is typically seen in hemiplegia or a spastic hip. The limb moves without flexion at the knee or ankle. The patient tries to clear the ground by circumducting the whole limb.

Trendelenburg gait is seen with the failure of the hip abduction, as seen in congenital or traumatic dislocation of the hip, non-union of fractures of the neck of the femur, or gluteus medius paralysis. In order to prevent falling, the torso tilts to the affected side, which is seen as a pelvis drop on the opposite side, and the body sways from side to side.

Quadriceps gait is a gait abnormality seen in polio due to quadriceps weakness and flexion deformity. The patient limps with one hand on the knee to prevent the loss of balance from buckling of the knee.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen in the X-Ray of a patient with right middle lobe consolidation?
questions.solution:
Right middle lobe consolidation is likely to result in right heart border obscuration. It may also outline the horizontal fissure above.

Silhouette sign (loss of silhouette sign or loss of outline sign) indicates the loss of a silhouette. 

Other commonly associated X-Ray patterns in the consolidation of specific regions:

  • Right upper lobe consolidation
    • Right paratracheal stripe obscuration
    • May outline the horizontal fissure below 
  • Right lower lobe consolidation
    • Right hemidiaphragm obscuration
  • Left upper lobe consolidation
    • Left heart border obscuration
    • Left paratracheal stripe obscuration
  • Left lower lobe consolidation
    • Left hemidiaphragm obscuration
    • Descending aorta obscuration

questions.text: All of the following clinical features are typically associated with an abscess in the pre-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, except _______.

choices.text: Swelling behind the angle of the jaw

questions.solution:
Glossopharyngeal nerve palsy is a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space and is not a feature of anterior compartment infection/ pre-styloid abscess.

Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by the styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

Presentation in pre-styloid abscess:

  • prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa
  • trismus (due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle) along with marked odynophagia
  • external swelling behind the angle of the jaw 

Presentation in post-styloid abscess:

  • Bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar
  • Paralysis of CN IX, X (vocal cord paralysis), XI, and XII and sympathetic chain (Horner’s syndrome)
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • There will not be any trismus

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

  Prestyloid Poststyloid
Relation to styloid Anterior Posterior
Relations

Medially: Tonsillar fossa

Laterally: Medial pterygoid muscle

Medially: Posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall

Laterally: Parotid gland
Contents Medial pterygoid muscle

Carotid artery

Jugular vein, IXth, Xth, XIth, XIIth cranial nerves

Sympathetic trunk
Presentation

Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa,

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus

The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Injury to of CN IX, X, XI, and XII leading to vocal cord paralysis

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

Swelling of the parotid region

questions.text: All of the following viruses replicate in the nucleus, except:
questions.solution:
Picornaviruses replicate in the cytoplasm, not in the nucleus. 

They are single-stranded RNA viruses that have icosahedral symmetry. 

Viruses with nuclear replication:

  • Herpesvirus
  • Polyomavirus
  • Papillomavirus
  • Parvovirus
  • Adenovirus

questions.text: A young man alleges that his wife has the capability to change herself to the form of other persons. He refuses to be convinced even after being given clear evidence to the contrary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will is known as intermetamorphosis.

Other options:

Option B: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Option C: Delusion of subjective doubles, also called Doppelganger, is when a person feels he has his own impostor (duplicate).

Option D: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: You would perform a Pinard's maneuver for _____.

choices.text: Delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech delivery
Delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery

questions.solution:
Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, and Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • McRoberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus (shown below).

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hepatitis B serology is false?

choices.text: High levels of IgM-specific anti-HBc are detected at the onset of clinical illness
At the start of resolution of the disease, HBeAg is replaced by anti-HBe, even before HBsAg disappears
Positive Anti-HBs is always indicative of HBV infection in the past
Small amounts of HBV DNA are usually detectable in the serum as long as HBsAg is present

questions.solution:
Positive Anti-HBs may also be seen in those who have undergone Hepatitis B vaccination, not just those with recent infection.

High titers of IgM-specific anti-HBc are detected at the onset of clinical illness. Its appearance in the serum is indicative of viral replication.

Antibody to HBsAg is first detected at a variable period after the disappearance of HBsAg. It is present in low concentrations. It may also be seen after vaccination

At the start of the resolution of the disease, HBeAg is replaced by anti-HBe, even before HBsAg disappears. But, interestingly, some patients can develop HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis with pre-core HBV mutants that result in absent HBeAg production but with continued viral progression.

HBV chronic carriers have persistent HBsAg for more than 6 months, in the presence of HBeAg or anti-HBe. HBsAg may persist for years after the loss of HBeAg. In acute disease, high titers of IgM-specific anti-HBc are observed, while low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers. Small amounts of HBV DNA are usually detectable in the serum as long as HBsAg is present.

World Hepatitis Day is commemorated each year on 28 July to enhance awareness of viral hepatitis, ‘I can’t wait to get tested’ is the new campaign theme for the year 2022. It will highlight the need to accelerate the fight against viral hepatitis and the importance of testing and treatment for the people who need it.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: An individual would be considered pre-diabetic if his HbA1c is __________.
questions.solution:
An individual would be considered pre-diabetic if his HbA1c is 5.7% to 6.4%.

Related Pearl: Abnormal Glucose Homeostasis

Individuals without overt diabetes can have abnormal glucose homeostasis. It is also called prediabetes or intermediate hyperglycemia. These people are at an increased risk of developing diabetes mellitus. Three categories of abnormal glucose homeostasis have been defined:

  • Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) – blood glucose levels between 140 and 199 mg/dL following an oral glucose challenge
  • Impaired fasting glucose (IFG) – fasting blood glucose 100 to 125 mg/dL 
  • HbA1c – 5.7-6.4%

Please note that impaired glucose tolerance and impaired fasting glucose are two distinct entities.

Related Pearl: ADA criteria for Diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus

Any one of the following:

  • Symptoms of diabetes plus Random Blood Glucose concentration ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • Fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.
  • Haemoglobin A1c ≥6.5%
  • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an oral glucose tolerance test.

Note: In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia and acute metabolic decompensation, these criteria should be confirmed by repeat testing on a different day.

questions.text:
Arrange the following foods in ascending order of the time taken for their gastric emptying.
  1. Protein-rich meal
  2. Carbohydrate-rich meal
  3. Fat-rich meal
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 2<1<3.

The type of food ingested determines the rate at which the stomach empties into the duodenum. The order of the time taken for gastric emptying:

 Carbohydrate-rich meal < Protein-rich meal < Fat-rich meal.

Another factor that influences the rate of gastric emptying is the osmotic pressure of the material entering the duodenum. Duodenal osmoreceptors sense the osmolality of the duodenal content and cause a decrease in gastric emptying.

questions.text: Which of the following obstetric grips and their corresponding use is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Pawlik's grip - To assess the presenting part
Lateral grip - To determine attitude of the baby
Pelvic grip - To determine degree of descent
Fundal grip - To determine lie/ fetal pole at the fundus

questions.solution:
Lateral grip assesses fetal orientation.

Leopold's maneuvers help assess the fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head. They are as follows:

  1. Fundal grip (first Leopold):
    • Assesses the uterine fundus.
    • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
    • The breech is felt as a large, irregular mass. 
    • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

  2. Lateral grip (second Leopold): 
    • Assesses fetal orientation.
    • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
    • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
    • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
    • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
    • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

  3. Pawlik's grip/ 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold):
    • Assesses the presenting part.
    • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
    • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.

  4. Deep pelvic grip/ 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):
    • Assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head.
    • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
    • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

Leopold Grip Importance
First Fundal To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlik 

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth Pelvic

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

questions.text: Which of the following statements about allopurinol is false?

choices.text: May precipitate acute gout attacks on initial treatment
Used in prevention of recurrent calcium stones
Used in prevention of tumor lysis syndrome
Patients who carry the HLA-B*58:01 allele are at a lower risk of allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS)

questions.solution:
Patients who carry the HLA-B*58:01 allele are at a higher risk of allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS).

Allopurinol and its primary metabolite alloxanthine will inhibit xanthine oxidase which converts xanthine to uric acid. At low concentration, it inhibits XO competitively while at high concentration it inhibits non-competitively.

Oral therapy with allopurinol is effective for:

  • Primary and secondary gout
  • Hyperuricemia secondary to malignancies - Used in prevention of tumor lysis syndrome 
  • Calcium oxalate calculi - Used in prevention of recurrent calcium stones

The aim of the therapy is to reduce serum uric acid to less than 6 mg/dL. The most common side effect of allopurinol is the hypersensitivity reactions that manifest after months of therapy. 

Tumor lysis syndrome is a condition that can occur spontaneously after the initiation of chemotherapy and is associated with certain metabolic disorders leading to end-organ damage. Metabolic disorders associated with tumor lysis syndrome are:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperuricemia

Tumor lysis syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with leukemia who have a very high white blood cell count. Signs and symptoms associated with tumor lysis syndrome can develop up to 72 hours after the initiation of chemotherapy. 

Patients with tumor lysis syndrome generally present with:

  • Abdominal pain and distension
  • Dysuria, oliguria, flank pain and hematuria
  • Anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, spasms, altered mental status, and tetany due to hypocalcemia
  • Weakness, and paralysis due to hyperkalemia

questions.text:
Which of the following scores can be used in the assessment of a preterm newborn with respiratory distress?

 

  1. Modified Bell's Staging
  2. Sarnat and Sarnat Staging
  3. Expanded New Ballard Score
  4. Silverman Anderson Score
  5. Downe's Score
questions.solution:
Both Silverman Anderson score and Downe's score can be used in the assessment of a preterm newborn with respiratory distress.

Silverman Anderson Retraction Score is more suited for preterms with respiratory distress, while the Downes’ Score is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. 

Downe’s score can be applied for any gestational age.
Downe’s score of >6 means impending respiratory failure.

The Expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • It can be used to calculate gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks.

questions.text: The most sensitive IHC marker for malignant melanoma is?
questions.solution:
The most sensitive marker for malignant melanoma is S-100.

Other markers for melanoma:

  • MELAN-A
  • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45
  • LDH

Vimentin is positive in mesotheliomas.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of testicular tumors?

choices.text: Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the gold standard treatment for excision of the primary tumor
Chest and abdominal axial imaging are  not the main staging tools
Recurrence usually occurs within the first 2 years and in the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
Option B is the false statement as chest and abdominal axial imaging are the main staging tools in the management of testicular tumors.

Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged 20 to 40 years and the second most common cancer in young men aged 15 to 19 years. 95% of testicular tumors are germ cell tumors; the rest originate from stromal cells (Leydig or Sertoli cells). Germ cell tumors can be classified as either seminomatous or nonseminomatous. Seminoma constitutes more than 50% of all testicular cancers. 

Most patients present with testicular pain or a testicular mass. Respiratory symptoms, back pain, weight loss, or gynecomastia may indicate metastatic disease (10–20%). A testicular mass is considered malignant till proven otherwise. Similarly, retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy in young men should be considered metastatic testicular cancer. 

The gold standard for the excision of a primary testicular tumor is a radical inguinal orchiectomy (Option A). A partial orchiectomy via an inguinal route may be considered in certain circumstances, such as lymphomas. Chest and abdominal axial imaging are the main staging tools for testicular tumors. The spread of testicular cancer follows an extremely predictable pattern. The interaortocaval lymph node is typically the first site of metastasis for right testicular cancer, followed by the paracaval and paraaortic lymph nodes. Left-sided testicular cancer rarely crosses to the paracaval lymph nodes. Tumor markers, distant metastases, and local stages are all included in clinical TNM staging.

Percutaneous testicular biopsy(Option 3) is contraindicated due to the risk of seeding in the scrotal wall. An open testicular biopsy by delivery of the testicle through the inguinal canal is recommended in cases where metastatic disease to the testicle is suspected. Recurrence usually occurs within the first two years and in the retroperitoneum(Option 4).

questions.text:
For which of the following patients should you offer TPT (Tuberculosis Preventive Therapy) without testing for TBI (Tuberculosis Infection)? HHC - House Hold Contact
  1. In HHC under 5 years of age
  2. In HHC over 5 years of age
  3. Adult on immunosuppressive therapy
  4. Adult having silicosis
  5. Adult on anti-TNF treatment
questions.solution:
In House Hold Contacts under 5 years of age, TPT will be offered without testing for TBI.

The NTEP guidelines recommend:

  • In HHC under 5 years of age, TPT will be offered without testing for TBI.
  • In HHC >5 years of age and adults, chest X-Ray and TBI testing would be offered wherever available. All efforts need to be made to ensure that CXR & TBI testing is made available. However, TPT must not be deferred in their absence.
  • In individuals who are on immunosuppressive therapy, having silicosis, on anti-TNF treatment, on dialysis, preparing for organ or hematologic transplantation, or in other vulnerable risk groups, treatment would always be preceded by testing.

The following TPT treatment options are recommended under National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) once active TB has been ruled out:

Target Population Treatment options
  • People living with HIV (adults and children >12 months)
  • Infants <12 months in contact with active TB
  • HHC (Household contact) below 5 years of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) patients
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)
  • 3-month weekly Isoniazid and Rifapentine(3HP) in persons older than 2 years
HHC 5 years and above of pulmonary TB patients (testing would be offered whenever available)
  • 3-month weekly Isoniazid and Rifapentine (3HP)
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)
Children/adults on immunosuppressive
therapy, silicosis, anti-TNF treatment, dialysis,
transplantation
  • 3-month weekly Isoniazid and Rifapentine (3HP)
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)

Dose of isoniazid : 

  • Age 10 years & older: 5 mg/kg/day
  • Age <10 years: 10 mg/kg/day (range, 7–15 mg)

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z

questions.text: Which of the following children would need a referral for developmental delay evaluation?

choices.text: A 5-month-old child who has not developed vocalization
A 9-month-old child who is unable to sit without support
A 20-month-old child who is unable to walk alone
A 2-year-old child who does not show imaginative play

questions.solution:
A 20-month-old child who is unable to walk alone would need evaluation for developmental delay.

The upper age-limit for the attainment of milestones:

  1. Visual fixation or following - 2 months
  2. Vocalization - 6 months
  3. Sitting without support - 10 months
  4. Standing with assistance - 12 months
  5. Hands and knees crawling - 14 months
  6. Standing alone - 17 months
  7. Walking alone - 18 months
  8. Single words - 18 months
  9. Imaginative play - 3 years

questions.text: Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in a patient with Forbes Disease or Cori's disease?
questions.solution:
Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori's disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. It is characterized by episodes of hypoglycemia which are often precipitated by fasting, not hyperglycemia.

Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. Accumulation of limit dextrins is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

questions.text:
Which of the following pedigree charts corresponds to the pattern of inheritance seen in G6PD deficiency?

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in image 1 is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G6PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected, and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

Other options: 
Option A: Image 3 is indicative of the mitochondrial inheritance pattern seen in MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes).

Option B: Image 2 is an example of autosomal recessive inheritance.

Option D: Image 4 is an example of X-linked dominant inheritance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immature defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism, unlike introjection, regression, and somatization, which are immature defense mechanisms.

Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses generally takes place through games or sports. Sublimation allows instincts to be channelled and not dammed up or diverted. Hence, in sublimation, feelings are acknowledged, modified, and directed toward a socially valued/acceptable goal so that modest instinctual satisfaction is achieved.

Mature defense mechanisms are healthy and adaptive throughout the life cycle. They are socially adaptive and useful in the integration of personal needs and motives, social demands, and interpersonal relations. They can underlie seemingly admirable and virtuous patterns of behaviour.

Other mature defense mechanisms are:

  • Anticipation
  • Humor
  • Altruism
  • Asceticism
  • Suppression

Immature defense mechanisms are usually triggered due to anxieties related to intimacy or its loss. These mechanisms are fairly common in preadolescent years and adult character disorders. Although they are regarded as socially awkward and undesirable, improvement in interpersonal relationships and personal maturity can alleviate it. Some of the immature defense mechanisms are:

Option B. Introjection involves taking up features from the external world and making them a part of oneself. Introjection of a loved object involves internalizing the characteristics of the object to ensure closeness and constant presence of the object in order to reduce the anxiety associated with separation from or loss of the object. Similarly, the introjection of a feared object involves internalizing the aggressive characteristics of the object and using it defensively to have the aggression under their control. Introjection can also take place from a sense of guilt.

Option C. Regression involves a return to a previous stage of development or functioning to avoid the anxieties or hostilities involved in later stages. This reflects a basic tendency to achieve instinctual gratification or to escape instinctual tension by returning to earlier modes and levels of gratification when later and more differentiated modes fail or involve intolerable conflict.

Option D. In somatization, psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms and tend to react to somatic symptoms rather than psychic ones.

Other immature defenses include:

  • Acting out
  • Blocking
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Passive–aggressive behaviour
  • Projection (non-psychotic)
  • Schizoid fantasy

Neurotic Defenses include:

  • Controlling
  • Displacement
  • Exterternalization
  • Inhibition
  • Intellectualization
  • Isolation
  • Rationalization
  • Reaction formation
  • Repression
  • Sexualization

Narcissistic-Psychotic Defenses include Projection, Denial, and Distortion.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding a hostile witness?
  1. Has motive for concealing part of the truth or motive for giving completely false evidence
  2. Has given willful false/ fabricated evidence
  3. A hostile witness can be cross-examined by the same side lawyer
  4. The first-hand knowledge rule is applicable to hostile witnesses only
  5. It is defined under section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act
questions.solution:
A hostile witness is one who has some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence. There must be some evidence to prove that the witness has retracted from his earlier statement or is not desirous of disclosing the truth, or has exhibited an element of hostility. If a witness is declared as hostile, he can be cross-examined by the same side lawyer.

IEA 45 defines expert witness. A person who has been trained or is skilled or has the knowledge, experience, or education in a technical or scientific subject, and is capable of drawing opinions and conclusions from the observed facts observed is termed an expert witness. Examples include doctors, firearm or fingerprints, or handwriting experts.

The first-hand knowledge rule refers to the concept that the witness must show that he was capable of perceiving the fact by one of his own senses and that he actually observed this fact. It is applicable to all common witness who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him/her.

Perjury is defined as the offense of wilfully telling an untruth or making a misrepresentation under oath. IPC 193 deals with punishment for false evidence. A person who intentionally gives false evidence or produces fabricated evidence for it to be used in a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years, and also liable to a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the nystagmus that is seen in patients with BPPV?

choices.text: Nystagmus appears after a latent period of 2–20 s
Nystagmus lasts as long as the position is maintained
Nystagmus is always in one direction

questions.solution:
In benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), the nystagmus lasts for less than a minute even if the triggering position is maintained. Nystagmus that lasts as long as the critical position is maintained is seen in the case of central lesions.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver: The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested. Then the examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

The features of nystagmus that differentiate between BPPV and central lesions:

Nystagmus BPPV Central lesions
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration <1 minute >1 minute/ lasts as long as critical position maintained
Direction fixed changing
Result on repetitions of the test nystagmus is not seen (fatigable) nystagmus persists (non-fatigable)
Symptoms during the test severe vertigo Absent/mild


The nystagmus of BPPV appears after a short latent period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower-placed ear. This is also associated with complaints of severe vertigo.

Benign positional paroxysmal vertigo is typically thought to be caused by the dislodgement of a piece of calcium carbonate from the otoconial membrane within one of the canals. The posterior canal is affected 90% of the time in benign positional paroxysmal vertigo, and lateral canal pathology causes approximately 8% of cases. The classical presentation of BPPV is recurrent, brief (<1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. 

The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver, displacing the otolith from the posterior canal. This ends the sensation of vertigo with positional changes relieving the symptoms. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following examination findings is unlikely to be seen in a patient with a fetus in transverse lie?

choices.text: Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
Fundal height is more than the period of amenorrhea.
Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side and soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis  in dorsoanterior position of fetus.

questions.solution:
Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea in transverse lie.

Transverse lie occurs when the long axis of the fetus lies perpendicularly to the maternal spine or centralized uterine axis.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator. The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common (60%)
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with an increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior 
  • Dorsoinferior

According to the position of the head, the fetal position is termed right or left, the left one being more common.

Abdominal examination findings:

On inspection, the uterus looks broader and is often asymmetrical. It does not maintain the pyriform shape.

Palpation:

  • Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea.
  • Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
  • Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side. A soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
    • In dorso-anterior: The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis 
    • In dorso-posterior: Irregular small parts are felt anteriorly
  • Pelvic grip: The lower pole of the uterus is empty.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the following poisoning agent, except _____.

choices.text: Ingestion results in cardiac symptoms only
Smoke from burning the plant is toxic
The plant may occasionally result in contact dermatitis

questions.solution:
The given plant is Nerium odorum. Ingestion results in cardiac, gastrointestinal, and other systemic symptoms.

Ingestion causes the following GI symptoms:

  • Difficulty in swallowing and articulation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Vomiting
  • Profuse frothy salivation and diarrhea.

The cardiac manifestations are:

  • Pulse is first slow and later rapid and weak
  • Hypotension
  • Fibrillation, A-V blocks

Other manifestations

  • Respirations are increased
  • Pupils are dilated
  • Muscular twitching & Tetanic spasms
  • Lock-jaw
  • Drowsiness
  • Coma
  • Respiratory paralysis and death occur. Death usually results from cardiac failure.

Flowers are usually white, pink, dark red, or pale yellow in colour. All parts of the plant including nectar, are poisonous. It contains several cardiac glycosides such as neriodorin, neriodorein, and karabin. The action of neriodorin mimics digitalis causing death due to cardiac failure. It can resist heat and hence can be found even in burnt dead bodies. 

 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Toxic manifestations of Datura

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-essential amino-acid that is both glucogenic and ketogenic?
questions.solution:
Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid that is both ketogenic and glucogenic. 

Phenylalanine, tryptophan, and isoleucine are also both ketogenic and glucogenic but are considered nutritionally essential amino acids.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical symptoms distinguishes polycythemia vera from other causes of erythrocytosis?
questions.solution:
Aquagenic pruritus distinguishes polycythemia vera from other causes of erythrocytosis. Vertigo, tinnitus, and systolic hypertension may be associated with any of the causes of erythrocytosis.

Polycythemia vera is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus. It is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm. The increase in the red cells is predominantly responsible for the clinical symptoms in this condition.

In 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years, there is increased myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of PV are:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Thrombocytosis- leads to venous arterial thrombosis, and hepatic venous thrombosis. Erythromelalgia is the erythema, burning, and pain in the extremities. It also occurs due to thrombocytosis.
  • Erythrocytosis- leads to hyperviscosity, leading to neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and systolic hypertension. 
  • Aquagenic pruritus - intense itching after contact with water of any temperature.
  • Hyperuricemia and gout- It may occur due to the large turnover of the hematopoietic stem cells.

Diagnosis: Criteria for diagnosis are given below:

Major criteria:

  1. Hb more than 16.5g/dL in males and 16g/dL in females or hematocrit of >49% in men and >48% in women.
  2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  3. Presence of JAK-2 mutation.

Minor criteria:

  • Subnormal erythropoietin levels.

Diagnosis requires all three major criteria or the first 2 major and 1 minor criterion.

Management:

  • Target Hb levels are <14 g/dL in males and <12 g/dL in females.
  • Periodic phlebotomy can be done to reduce hyperviscosity and to maintain the red cell mass. It is usually done at 3-month intervals.
  • Anticoagulants are given when there is thrombosis.
  • Allopurinol can be given to control hyperuricemia.
  • Ruxolitinib which is a nonspecific JAK2 inhibitor, pegylated IFN-α, or PUVA therapy can be used for intractable pruritis.
  • Ruxolitinib or pegylated IFN-α can be used to manage symptomatic splenomegaly.
  • Anagrelide which is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor is used to reduce platelet count in these patients.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Which of the following muscles of the perineal body is unpaired?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal muscles of the anal canal are unpaired.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body. They are:

  • Two unpaired 
    • External anal sphincter
    • Longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Four paired
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Superficial transverse perinei
    • Deep transverse perinei
    • Levator ani

The perineal body is the central fibrous skeleton of the perineum. It is situated in the medial plane about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of the penis. In females, sphincter urethro-vaginalis is also attached to the perineal body. Perineal body has a pyramidal shape in males and a wedge shape in females.

The perineal body is innervated by the perineal nerve, the larger and inferior terminal branch of the perineal pudendal nerve. It is directed forward under the internal pudendal artery. 

The perineal body supports the pelvic organs in females and it may get damaged during parturition or childbirth. This may result in prolapse of :

  • Urinary bladder
  • Uterus
  • Ovaries
  • Rectum

The image below shows the muscles of the perineum:

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: Which of the following signs of pneumoperitoneum is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Rigler's sign - Air on both sides of the bowel wall
Football sign - Air outlines the peritoneal cavity
Cupola sign - Air around the urinary bladder
Inverted V sign - Air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament

questions.solution:
Cupola sign refers to the presence of air under the central tendon of the diaphragm.

Signs of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs:
    • Double wall sign/ Rigler's sign/ bas-relief sign - Air is seen on both sides of the bowel wall.
    • Telltale triangle sign/ triangle sign - Triangle of gas formed between three loops of bowel or between the abdominal wall and 2 loops of bowel.
  • Peritoneal ligament-related signs:
    • Football sign - Air outlines the confines of the peritoneal cavity
    • Falciform ligament sign -  Air outlines the falciform ligament
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign/ inverted "V" sign - Air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament
    • Urachus sign - Air outlines the urachus
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Cupola sign - Accumulation of air under the central tendon
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign - Air outlines the ligamentum teres
    • Hepatic edge sign -  cigar-shaped free-air pocket in the subhepatic region. It tracks superomedial following the contours of the liver
    • Lucent liver sign - Reduction of hepatic radiodensity due to accumulation of free gas anterior to the liver
    • Morison pouch sign/ Doge cap sign - Triangular/ crescentic gas lucency bound by the 11th rib
    • Periportal free gas sign

questions.text: All of the following are valid recommendations regarding wound care in cases of category III dog bites, except ______.

choices.text: Wound should be thoroughly washed and dried followed by application of alcohol to the wound
If suturing is unavoidable, rabies immunoglobulin should be infiltrated in the depth and around the wound and suturing should be delayed by a few hours
In life threatening situations, minimal loose sutures maybe applied to arrest bleeding
Routine cauterization of wound should be performed wherever feasible to reduce incidence of nerve infection

questions.solution:
Wound cauterization is not recommended as it leaves a bad scar and does not confer any additional advantage over washing the wound with water and soap.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is unavoidable, rabies immunoglobulin should be infiltrated in the depth and around the wound, and suturing should be delayed by a few hours. This delay in suturing allows the diffusion of antibodies in the tissues.
  • In life-threatening situations, minimal loose sutures may be applied to arrest bleeding.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.

  • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each.
  • Zagreb regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, followed by 1 dose on days 7 and 21 each.

Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Run amok and amotivational syndrome are clinical presentations that are associated with the abuse of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Run Amok and Amotivational syndrome are associated with the abuse of Cannabis sativa.

Amotivational syndrome is characterized by lethargy and a lack of interest in day-to-day activities.

Run amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text:
Match the following skin lesions with their most suitable clinical descriptions.
  1. Polycyclic
  2. Arcuate
  3. Nummular
  4. Annular
questions.solution:
The correct match is option A: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Image 1 shows a psoriatic plaque which is shaped as a filled circular lesion. This is known as nummular shape.

 

Image 2 depicts annular lesions which can be described as open circles with different central skin when compared to the rim. It is seen in tinea corporis and granuloma annulare.

Image 3 shows arcuate lesions which are incomplete circular lesions, seen in urticaria.

Image 4 shows chronic plaque psoriasis and is best described as polycyclic.

Well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with silvery scales characteristic of chronic plaque psoriasis. Polycyclic skin lesions are present as circles that have merged together. In severe cases of psoriasis, plaques grow and merge into one another forming polycyclic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is Czerny's retractor?
questions.solution:
Image 2 shows Czerny's retractor (shown below) is a double-ended retractor with two prongs on one end and a blade with a lip on the other. It is used during laparotomy for superficial skin retraction.

A double hook retractor (Image 3) is best suited for retracting the skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision.

Uses of a double hook retractor (shown below):

  • To retract skin flap during sebaceous cyst excision. 
  • Skin retraction during venesection. 
  • Skin and thyroid isthmus retraction during tracheostomy.

 

Image 1: Travers retractor (shown below) is a self-retaining retractor. It is used to retract the skin and subcutaneous tissues during intermediate-type operations, such as 

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy

Incorrect usage can traumatize the skin - the retractor has to be repositioned as the incision is deepened.

Image 4: Mollison’s mastoid retractor (shown below) is self-retaining and hemostatic. It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Prevotella is false?

choices.text: Cultures of P. melaninogenica produce red fluorescence when exposed to ultraviolet light
The color of the colonies is due to a hemin derivative
Cefoxitin is the drug of choice for Prevotella infections

questions.solution:
Clindamycin is the drug of choice for Prevotella infections. Penicillin, metronidazole, cefoxitin, and cefotetan can also be used for the management of Prevotella infections, but are not the drugs of choice.

Prevotella species are gram-negative anaerobic rods or coccobacilli. The most commonly isolated Prevotella species are P. melaninogenica, P. bivia, and P. disiens. P. melaninogenica is associated with upper respiratory tract infections. P. bivia and P. disiens occur in the female genital tract. Prevotella species are also found in brain and lung abscesses, empyema, pelvic inflammatory disease, and tubo-ovarian abscesses.

Cultures of P. melaninogenica and dressings from wounds infected with it produce red fluorescence when on exposure to ultraviolet light. P. melaninogenica produces a black or brown color colonies. Interestingly, the color of the colonies is not due to the melanin pigment, as was once thought, but due to a hemin derivative.

Related Pearl: Oxygen Requirements of Bacteria

 Feature Examples

Always require oxygen for their growth. 

Cannot ferment or respire anaerobically.

Bordetella sp

Require small amounts of oxygen (2–10%) for aerobic respiration. Higher oxygen concentrations are inhibitory.

Can grow aerobically or anaerobically based on the surrounding environment

Are indifferent to Oxygen. They are basically anaerobic organisms but can tolerate oxygen.

questions.text: A young man presented to the ER with a fever and suppurative lymphadenopathy of his left axilla. The histopathological examination of the axillary node reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the histopathological image showing stellate granuloma point to a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease caused by Bartonella henselae.

The clinical presentation includes a linear pustular lesion at the site of a cat's scratch and regional lymphadenopathy. The reservoir for B. henselae is cat, which infects humans through contact with skin lesions. It is usually self-limited and treated symptomatically with analgesics and drainage of excessively large lymph nodes. Azithromycin helps shorten the recovery period and lymph node swelling. 

It is also associated with bacillary angiomatosis, which are vascular tumors that appear as red papules on the skin, mucosa, and other locations, which resemble Kaposi sarcoma and bacillary peliosis involving the liver and spleen.

Cat-scratch disease is also known as subacute regional lymphadenitis. 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

Silicosis

Berylliosis

questions.text: Commissural fibers are located in all of the following places, except ______.

choices.text: Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
In the superior lamina of the pineal gland

questions.solution:
The internal capsule predominantly contains projection fibers, not commissural fibers.

The locations of the commissural fibers are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion. There is no history of trauma to the head or scalp. The child is otherwise healthy and investigations are normal. His skull and spine X-rays appear as below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following characteristic finding would be seen on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the x-ray image showing a punched-out lytic lesion and vertebra plana is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy.

The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhan cells with folded nuclei.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease)
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: Which of the following lesions is pathognomonic for leprosy?
questions.solution:
Iris pearls are pathognomonic for leprosy. These are caused by uveitis and appear as pearly white nodules at the pupillary border of the iris. Dead lepra bacilli are present in the nodules.

Ocular features in leprosy:

  • Anterior uveitis
  • Keratitis
  • Miosis & iris atrophy
  • Iris nodules
  • Episcleritis/ scleritis
  • Retinal pearls
  • Uveal effusion
  • Madarosis

Other options:

  • Brushfield spots are seen in Down’s syndrome. These are areas of focal stromal hyperplasia surrounded by areas of relative hypoplasia. The finding is more easily seen in light-colored irides.

Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas that are pathognomonic for neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Koeppe’s nodules are seen in granulomatous uveitis and are present at the pupillary border.

Note: Nodules within the iris stroma in granulomatous uveitis are called Busacca’s nodules.

questions.text: Trombiculid mites are the vectors for the transmission of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Trombiculid mites are the vectors for the transmission of scrub typhus.

Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in trombiculid mites. Transovarian transmission is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari.

The image below shows a trombiculid mite.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not a direct thrombin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Fondaparinux is an indirect thrombin inhibitor.

It is a synthetic analog of the pentasaccharide unit of heparin that binds and activates antithrombin. Activation of antithrombin causes the inactivation of factor Xa. So it is also described as an indirect factor Xa inhibitor.

It is not a direct factor Xa inhibitor. Direct factor Xa inhibitors include rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban
