questions.text: Perl's Prussian blue staining of the bone marrow aspirate of a patient reveals the following. Which of the following is used in the treatment of his anemia?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a ringed sideroblast. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anaemia.

Pyridoxine 100 - 200 mg per day for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anaemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy are also indicated. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anaemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent. However, no definitive treatment is available for hereditary and idiopathic types of sideroblastic anaemia.

Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue stain. Based on aetiology, sideroblastic anaemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anaemia is an X-linked disorder caused due to a defect in the activity of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers while males have moderate to marked anaemia and manifest in childhood or during early adulthood

Acquired sideroblastic anaemia:

I) Primary acquired:

  • Also called idiopathic or refractory acquired sideroblastic anaemia
  • Occurs in middle-aged and older individuals of both sexes
  • Due to the reduced activity of the enzyme ALA synthetase, there is disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors at the level of hematopoietic stem cell
  • Moderate to severe anaemia, which appears insidiously
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia may also be seen
  • Regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification and thus considered preleukaemic

II) Secondary acquired:

May appear secondary to 

  • Drugs, chemicals and toxins: Isoniazid, Cycloserine, Chloramphenicol, Cyclophosphamide, Alcohol, Lead, etc.,
  • Haematological disorders: myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, acute leukaemia, myeloma, lymphoma and hemolytic anaemia.
  • Miscellaneous: Carcinoma, myxoedema, rheumatoid arthritis and SLE.

Laboratory findings:

  • Peripheral smear: Hypochromic, microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anaemia
  • Absolute values: MCV, MCH and MCHC are reduced except in acquired type, where MCV is raised.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with macronormoblastic erythropoiesis. Marrow iron stores are raised. Pathognomonic ring sideroblasts are present.
  • Serum ferritin: Raised
  • Serum iron: Raised
  • TIBC: Normal
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Normal

questions.text: Penicillin is considered the drug of first choice in all of the following, except ________.
questions.solution:
The drug of first choice for the treatment of relapsing fever, which is caused by Borrelia recurrentis, is Doxycycline. Though penicillin G or erythromycin can be used in its management, they are not the drugs of first choice. 

Penicillin G is considered the drug of first choice for the management of infections by:

  1. Leptospira
  2. Treponema pallidum
  3. Treponema pertenue
  4. Neisseria meningitidis
  5. Clostridium (along with clindamycin)
  6. Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) (in combination)
  7. Streptococcus, hemolytic, groups A, B, C, G (in combination)
  8. Viridans streptococci (in combination)

questions.text: Albert staining of Corynebacterium diphtheria would reveal:

choices.text: Bluish-black metachromatic granules  and green bacillary body
Green metachromatic granules  and Bluish-black bacillary body
Dark green metachromatic granules  and light green bacillary body
Dark blue metachromatic granules  and light blue bacillary body

questions.solution:
Bluish-black metachromatic granules and green bacillary bodies are seen with Albert's staining of Corynebacterium diptheriae.

Albert's stain contains toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green which have an affinity for acidic cytoplasm, both being basic dyes. Albert’s stain, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin / Babes Ernst Granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 Procedure for Albert's staining:

  • A heavy smear of the bacterial isolate is prepared on a glass slide and allowed to dry without fixing.
  • Albert’s stain is applied for (3-4) minutes then it is washed with water and Albert’s iodine is applied for one minute.
  • Wash with water and let it dry with blotting paper.

Results:

  • Metachromatic granules: Bluish-black
  • Bacillary body or protoplasm: Green

Uses: 

  • Albert staining is useful in the demonstration of metachromatic granules.
  • The presence of metachromatic granules helps to distinguish C.diphtheriae from diphtheriods which lack them.

 

Image shows Albert's stain of C. diphtheria 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration will best help bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism?
questions.solution:
The sublingual route of administration helps bypass the hepatic first-pass metabolism.

Hepatic first-pass metabolism occurs in drugs administered via the oral, rectal, and nasogastric routes.

When drugs are given orally, they are absorbed in the intestine and reach the liver through the portal vein. During this process, the drug is acted on by enzymes of the liver and intestine. Additionally, the liver may excrete part of the drug in the bile, further reducing the bioavailability. This is called the first-pass metabolism.

In all the other routes, the drug directly enters systemic circulation without reaching the liver.

Note: Bioavailability is the fraction of an administered dose of unchanged drug that reaches systemic circulation. Hence, the bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously (IV) is 100%. It is neither subjected to the first-pass metabolism as in the oral route nor does it depend on local factors as in subcutaneous, intramuscular, or transdermal.

questions.text: Endometrial biopsy is indicated in patients with any of the following, except _______.

choices.text: The endometrium is not adequately visualized on sonography
The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)

questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Endometrial biopsy is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom associated with long COVID?
questions.solution:
Fatigue is the most common symptom associated with long COVID/ Post-COVID sequelae.

Symptoms associated with long COVID/ Post-COVID sequelae include, but are not limited to:

  1. Nausea
  2. Vomiting
  3. Dysgeusia
  4. Loss of appetite
  5. Abdominal pain
  6. Hematemesis /melena
  7. Dysphagia
  8. GERD
  9. Constipation
  10. Fatigue
  11. Nocturia (frequent urination during the night which disturbs sleep)
  12. Increased froth in urine
  13. Anorexia (loss of appetite)
  14. Headache
  15. Leg Swelling 
  16. Increased requirement of anti-hypertensives
  17. Breathing difficulty
  18. Orthopnea (Breathing difficulty during lying down)
  19. Changes in concentration
  20. Impaired memory
  21. Persistent muscle weakness and myalgias
  22. Headaches
  23. Sleep disorders
  24. Dizziness
  25. Impairment in smell (Anosmia)
  26. Rarely new-onset status epilepticus, stroke, acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuritis (AIDP), autonomic dysfunction such as orthostatic symptoms.
  27. Non-specific sensory complaints such as paresthesias, numbness, tingling in limbs

questions.text: All of the following typically affect the anterior mediastinum, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mesenchymal tumors typically occur in the middle mediastinum.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the use of cardiac biomarker troponin for the workup of a patient with suspected myocardial infarction is false?

choices.text: Troponin should be measured at presentation
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has poor negative predictive value
Troponin should be repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays
Troponin should be repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin

questions.solution:
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has an excellent negative predictive value. This means that more than 2-3 hours after symptom onset, a negative troponin is sufficient to exclude a diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

In patients with suspected ACS, troponin is:

  • Measured at presentation
  • Repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin
  • Repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays

Additional measurements of troponin beyond 3–6 h may be warranted when the clinical condition still suggests possible ACS or if there is diagnostic uncertainty. 

Cardiac-specific troponin T and cardiac-specific troponin I are the preferred biomarkers for detection of MI.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm?

choices.text: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 5.5 cm with Marfan's syndrome
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 7 cm
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter of  6.5 cm
Descending thoracic aneurysm which is enlarging about 0.2 cm/ year

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the patient in whom the descending thoracic aneurysm is enlarging at about 0.2 cm/ year, is not considered for operative repair. 

The indications for operative repair of the thoracic aortic aneurysm are given in the table below:

Clinical scenario Indication for operative repair
Symptomatic aneurysm Any size
Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm

≥5.5cm
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm
When the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased > 0.5 cm per year
Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter or > 6 cm
When the diameter of descending  aortic aneurysm has increased  > 1 cm per year
Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve 4-5cm

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her friend with complaints that she eats large amounts of food when she is alone and food wrappers are often found hidden in her room. Once or twice a week, she vomits after having a large meal. On examination, erosion of teeth enamel is noted and her BMI is found to be 19. What is considered the benchmark first-line treatment for her condition?

choices.text: Eating and vomiting prevention as part of exposure and response prevention

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, with normal weight, is suggestive of bulimia nervosa. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is the benchmark, first-line treatment for bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is characterized by a morbid fear of weight gain and episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory purging behaviors. DSM 5 diagnostic criteria for bulimia nervosa are:

  • A recurrent episode of binge eating characterized by
    • eating relatively a large amount of food in a short span of time
    • lack of control during the episode
  • Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors in order to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, or excessive exercise.
  • This behavior is present at least once a week for 3 months
  • There is fear of becoming fat or wanting to lose weight
  • It does not occur during the periods of anorexia nervosa

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy.

CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, body image, etc. Drugs usually used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is based on the psychological significance of the cognitive triad i.e. people's beliefs about themselves, their personal world (including the people in their lives), and their future. Problematic and biased interpretations related to this cognitive triad may lead to excessive emotional distress. CBT is used in the treatment of depression, phobia, anxiety & panic disorders, OCD, personality disorders, and somatoform disorders.

The three components of cognitive therapy are: 

  • Didactic aspects: Explaining to patients the cognitive triad, schemas, and faulty logic. The therapist must explain all the aspects of treatment.
  • Cognitive techniques: These involve four steps-
    • Eliciting automatic thoughts- Asking the patient about the thought that causes the emotional reaction in them.
    • Testing the validity of the automatic thoughts
    • Identifying the general maladaptive assumptions
    • Testing the validity of maladaptive assumptions
  • Behavioral techniques like relaxation techniques, cognitive rehearsal, self-reliance, etc.

Other options:

Option A. Dialectical behavioral therapy(DBT) is a long-term behavioral intervention that is shown to reduce suicidal behavior in adults and has also shown efficacy in borderline personality disorder. The goal of the therapy is to improve interpersonal relationships and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques that involve advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

Option C. Systemic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counterconditioning whereby the person overcomes anxiety elicited by a situation or an object by approaching the feared situation gradually, in a relaxed state. It is useful in phobias, obsessions, compulsions, and some sexual disorders. It has three steps: relaxation training, hierarchy construction, and desensitization of the stimulus.

Option D. Exposure and response prevention is a strategy within CBT that is effective in the management of OCD. It is also useful in other conditions like tics.

questions.text: Insulin-induced hypoglycemia test is contraindicated in all of the following, except _______.
questions.solution:
Adult growth hormone deficiency (AGHD) is an indication for performing an insulin-induced hypoglycemia test. 

Insulin-induced hypoglycemia test is done by administering 0.05–0.1 U/kg. After reduction of glucose to ~40 mg/dL, most individuals experience neuroglycopenic symptoms. Peak GH release occurs at 60 min and remains elevated for up to 2 h.

About 90% of healthy adults exhibit GH responses >5 μg/L; AGHD is defined by a peak GH response to hypoglycemia of <3 μg/L.

Though insulin-induced hypoglycemia is safe when performed under suitable supervision, it is contraindicated in patients with diabetes, ischemic heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, or epilepsy and in elderly patients. Alternative stimulatory tests include intravenous arginine (30 g), GHRH (1 μg/kg), oral ghrelin receptor agonist (0.5 mg/kg), and glucagon (1 mg). Combinations of these tests may evoke GH secretion in subjects who are not responsive to a single test.

questions.text: All of the following are potentially sensitizing events for rhesus alloimmunization, except ______.
questions.solution:
Vaginal ultrasound is not a potentially sensitizing event for rhesus alloimmunization.

RCOG guidelines for anti–D prophylaxis:

1. All Rh-negative women should be offered anti-D

First trimester indications: (300 mcg)

  • Chorionic villus sampling
  • Miscarriage
  • Termination of pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy

2nd & 3rd-trimester indications: (300 mcg) 

  • Amniocentesis, cordocentesis
  • Obstetric hemorrhage
  • Abdominal trauma
  • External cephalic version

2. All Rh D-negative women should be given a single dose of 1500 units (300 mcg) of anti-D between 28 - 30 weeks of pregnancy.

3. Postnatally within 72 hours.

4. All women who deliver Rh D-positive baby should have quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage to guide appropriate dose of anti-D prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about epistaxis balloons is false?

choices.text: Contraindicated in patients with significant maxillofacial trauma
Contraindicated in patients with base of skull fractures
Not suitable for use in patients with posterior epistaxis
Patient should be seated in upright sniffing position for inserting the balloon

questions.solution:
Epistaxis balloons can be used for the management of both anterior epistaxis and posterior epistaxis.

There are various epistaxis balloons that are available for the management of both anterior and posterior epistaxis. Posterior epistaxis is often treated with double-balloon devices, which have separate anterior and posterior balloons. The patient is sat in an upright sniffing position and the balloon is advanced gently parallel to the floor of the nasal cavity till the catheter tip is seen via the oropharynx while looking through the mouth. Following this, the balloon is inflated using saline/ water and gently pulled back till it snugly fits into the posterior choana.   


Skull base fracture and significant maxillofacial or nasal bone trauma are considered absolute contraindications for the use of epistaxis balloons. Severe nasal septal deviation is considered a relative contraindication due to the difficulty that may result in the insertion of the balloon device.

The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching the nose 
  2. Hippocratic or Trotter’s method
  3. Cauterization
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing 
  6. Endoscopic cauterisation 
  7. Ligation  (the order of ligation is sphenopalatine artery → internal maxillary artery → external carotid artery → anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.)
  8. Embolization

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the ascending order of their typical ages of occurrence.
  1. Union of Xiphoid process and body
  2. Complete fusion of medial end of the clavicle
  3. Greater tubercle fuses with the head of the humerus
  4. Greater cornu of the hyoid bone unites with the body
questions.solution:
The respective ages of occurrence are

  1. Union of Xiphoid process and body ~ 40 years of age
  2. Complete fusion of medial end of clavicle - 20-21 years of age
  3. Greater tubercle fuses with the head of the humerus - 5 years of age
  4. Greater cornu of the hyoid bone unites with the body - 40-60 years of age

 

Age Age determination
<5 years The appearance of ossification centers
5-16 years Analysis of hand and wrist
>16 years(male) Complete fusion of distal radius or ulna
>16 years(female) Complete fusion of distal ulna
>18 years(male) Complete fusion of distal femur or proximal tibia
>18 years(female) Complete fusion of iliac crest
>21 years Complete fusion of medial end of the clavicle

The sternum is formed from the fusion of Manubrium, 4 sternebrae(body), and the xiphoid process. The fusion of sternebrae occurs from below upwards, followed by its fusion to the xiphoid process and then the fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum.

Manubrio-sternal joint 60-70 years
1st and 2nd Sternebrae 25 years 
2nd and 3rd sternebrae 20 years
3rd and 4th sternebrae 15 years
Xiphoid process and body 40-45 years

questions.text: Which of the following charts and their respective uses are incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
LogMAR charts are used for testing visual acuity, not for visual field defects.

LogMAR is an acronym for the base-10 logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution. It refers to the ability to resolve the elements of an optotype. It addresses many of the deficiencies of the Snellen chart, and is the standard means of VA measurement in research and increasingly in clinical practice.

Hess chart is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing the field of a binocular single vision. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

Incomitant strabismus is one where squint generally results from the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies like extraocular muscle palsy, thyroid ophthalmopathy, blow-out fracture, myasthenia gravis, etc. The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background.

An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

Jaeger’s chart is used to measure near vision. The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest as N48. It is held at a distance of 35 cm away from the patient. Snellen's near vision chart can also be used.

The image below shows Jaeger's chart.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the roles of posttranslationally modified histones is false?

choices.text: Acetylation of core histones is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication
Phosphorylation of histone H1 is associated with the condensation of chromosomes
Sumoylation of histones is associated with transcription activation
ADP-ribosylation of histones is associated with DNA repair

questions.solution:
Sumoylation of histones (SUMO - Small Ubiquitin-related MOdifier) is associated with transcription repression.

Other possible roles of posttranslationally modified histones

  • Acetylation of core histones is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication.
  • Phosphorylation of histone H1 is associated with the condensation of chromosomes during the replication cycle.
  • ADP-ribosylation of histones is associated with DNA repair.
  • Methylation of histones is correlated with activation and repression of gene transcription.
  • Acetylation of histones H3 and H4 is associated with the activation or inactivation of gene transcription.
  • Monoubiquitylation is associated with gene activation, repression, and heterochromatic gene silencing.

questions.text: Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes, crazy pavement pattern on HRCT, and progressive massive fibrosis are most likely to be associated with which of the following pneumoconioses?
questions.solution:
Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes, crazy pavement pattern on HRCT, and progressive massive fibrosis are most likely to be associated with silicosis.

Silicosis is a common concern for people working in granite mining industries. Silica is found in rock, granite, slate, and sandstone. People working in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying are exposed to silica. The active molecule that causes silicosis is free silica or crystalline silica (quartz).

Silicosis can present as:

  • Acute silicosis - due to heavy exposure in closed spaces and they manifest within 2 years.
  • Chronic silicosis (simple silicosis) - due to long-term (10 to 30 years), less intense exposure.
  • Complicated silicosis - simple silicosis may progress to complicated silicosis that presents with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion.

Calcification of hilar lymph nodes leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes, and there is no impairment in lung function. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) and is associated with significant impairment of lung function.

Note: Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
ARPKD is most likely to be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene (which encodes a protein called fibrocystin) on chromosome 6p. The severe form manifests in utero or in infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood. All affected individuals have some degree of congenital hepatic fibrosis. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.

ADPKD is usually clinically silent. Many cases remain asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life and are diagnosed incidentally. PKD-1 mutations cause more severe disease than PKD-2 mutations. The following clinical features may be seen in symptomatic patients:

  • Abdominal mass
  • Back or flank pain 
  • Recurrent UTIs - Renal cyst infections by Gram-negative bacteria are common
  • Nephrolithiasis - most commonly uric acid stones
  • Hematuria
  • Cardiac:
    • Hypertension - early feature  
    • Left ventricular hypertrophy
    • Mitral valve prolapse, valvular insufficiency
  • Extra-renal:
    • Intracranial aneurysms
    • Hepatic cysts

As the cysts grow they compress on the surrounding normal tissue which leads to a progressive reduction in the GFR. Eventually, it leads to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by the fifth decade of life.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Bronchoalveolar lavage from a patient with pneumoconiosis showed Alternaria species. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Woodworker's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Alternaria species, and Bacillus subtilis in persons exposed to oak, cedar, pine, and mahogany dust.

Bird fancier's lung is caused by proteins derived from birds like pigeons and parakeets in persons exposed to their feathers and droppings.

Machine operator’s lung is caused by Pseudomonas and Mycobacteria species in persons exposed to metal working fluid.

Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by thermophilic actinomycetes like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula (formerly known as Micropolyspora faeni). It occurs due to inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction.

questions.text: Any of the following may be used for the management of a patient with mild scoliosis, except _____.
questions.solution:
SOMI brace is used in cervical spine injury, not in scoliosis.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Braces used in scoliosis:

  • Milwaukee brace : 
    • Originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), introduced in the 1940s
    • Less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces
    • Still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine
  • Boston brace:
    • It is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 
    • It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside.
    • It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 
  • Risser's cast :
    • Body cast that extends up to the cervical spine and touches the chin and skull
    • A hole is cut in the abdominal region to make breathing easy
  • Charleston bending brace & Providence brace:
    • Used while laying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours
    • Best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed a sudden onset weakness of the left side of the body with facial deviation to the right side. On examination, he was tall and thin with elongated limbs and an ocular finding is shown in the image below. Evaluation reveals homocystinuria. Intake of which of the following should be reduced in his diet?
questions.solution:
Methionine intake should be reduced in patients with homocystinuria.

Homocystinuria is an important cause of pediatric stroke. It is most commonly caused by a defect in cystathionine β synthase enzyme leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and blood. They are generally normal at birth and the first sign is subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) seen after 3 years of age.

Manifestations of homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioural disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic lab findings.

 

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy?

choices.text: Abnormal delay in initiating IgG synthesis in some infants
Spontaneous resolution occurs in most cases
It is seen in infants of both sexes
It occurs due to a T cell defect

questions.solution:
Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy occurs due to a B cell defect.

Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy is due to an abnormal delay in initiating IgG synthesis in some infants. Maternal IgG is slowly catabolized in the newborn. Usually, the infant begins synthesizing his/ her own lgG by 2 months. Delay in this results in the transient immunodeficiency. Recurrent otitis media and respiratory infections are commonly associated. Between 18 and 30 months of age, spontaneous recovery occurs. It may be found in infants of both sexes.

Treatment with gamma globulin may be required in some cases but it is not recommended prophylactically as it may cause negative feedback inhibition of lgG synthesis thereby prolonging the condition.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding electrolyte status in severe acidosis?

choices.text: Total body Na+ is markedly depleted
Plasma Na+ becomes low when Na+ loss exceeds H2O loss
Plasma K+ levels are usually normal

questions.solution:
Total body K+ is reduced in case of severe acidosis, not increased. 

In severe acidosis,

  • Total body Na+ is markedly depleted
  • When Na+ loss exceeds water loss, plasma Na+ is also low.
  • Total body K+ is also low in severe acidosis
  • The plasma K+ is usually normal because:
    • Extra Cellular Fluid (ECF) volume is reduced.
    • K+ moves from cells to ECF when the ECF H+ concentration is high.
    • Lack of insulin-induced entry of K+ into cells.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Sanger sequencing, except ____.

choices.text: ddNTP is used as it doesn't allow further elongation of DNA
It is used for DNA sequencing
Sanger’s reagent is 1- fluoro 2,4 dinitro benzene
Automated DNA sequencing employs techniques that require the use of radioisotopes

questions.solution:
Techniques that do not require radioisotopes are employed in automated DNA sequencing.  The manual enzymatic Sanger method employs specific dideoxynucleotides that terminate DNA strand synthesis at specific nucleotides as the strand is synthesized on purified single-stranded template DNA.

The Sanger method is used for DNA sequencing. This method uses the mechanism of synthesis of DNA by DNA polymerases. In the process of synthesis of DNA, the 3'-hydroxyl group of primer reacts with an incoming dNTP to form a new phosphodiester bond. This reaction is catalyzed by DNA polymerase.

In the Sanger sequencing method, ddNTP is used because it halts the DNA synthesis. ddNTPs can bind to the template strand but lack the 3'-hydroxyl group which is required to add the next nucleotide. The products of this reaction are a mixture of DNA strands of varying lengths. This mixture is then separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and autoradiography. This produces a pattern of bands from which the DNA sequence can be read.

The image given below shows the steps involved in Sanger's method. 

Sanger’s technique was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins. The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin. Sanger’s reagent is 1- fluoro 2,4 dinitro benzene.

questions.text:
According to the WHO guidelines, which of the following statements are true regarding HPV vaccination?
  1. 3 doses schedule is recommended for young women aged 15-20 years
  2. 3 doses with a 6-month interval are recommended for women older than 21 years
  3. 3 doses (or at least 2 doses) are recommended for immunocompromised individuals
  4. Regardless of the duration of delay, interrupted schedules should be resumed without repeating previous doses
  5. All three HPV vaccines can be co-administered with other live and non-live vaccines using separate syringes and different injection sites
questions.solution:
1 or 2 doses schedule is recommended for young women aged 15-20 years and 2 doses with a 6-month interval is recommended for women older than 21 years.

As per the December 2022 WHO Position on HPV vaccines, the recommendations for different age groups are as follows:
  • 1 or 2 doses schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14 years.
  • 1 or 2 doses schedule for young women aged 15-20 years.
  • 2 doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21 years.
  • A minimum of 2 doses and when feasible 3-doses remain necessary for those known to be immunocompromised and/or HIV-infected. 

    All three HPV vaccines can be co-administered with other live and non-live vaccines using separate syringes and different injection sites. Regardless of the duration of delay, interrupted schedules should be resumed as soon as possible without repeating previous doses.

WHO SAGE (Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization) recommendations regarding vaccination against HPV (Human papilloma virus) have been changed to 1 dose only. This is because a single dose has been found to provide adequate protection as comparable to 2 doses. This can help in wider coverage of vaccination of all girls in low-middle income countries.

Note: Cervavac is India's first indigenously prepared quadrivalent HPV (qHPV) vaccine.
  • Targeted strains: 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • Targeted group: 9-26 years of age
  • Dose and route of administration: 0.5 ml, IM.

The other available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent :16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, CA cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia

Administration 0, 1, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6months , i.m
Administered gender Female and male Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years  11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male n female

Females:11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males:11-12 years

9-15 years - FDA approved

January is Cervical Cancer Awareness Month, observed to raise awareness about cervical cancer and HPV vaccination. On this Cervical Cancer Awareness Month, the messages are clear.

Get informed: Find out the facts about cervical cancer & HPV that causes it. Help educate other women in your life.
Get screened: Cervical cancer screening typically starts at age 30 and is repeated periodically.
Get vaccinated: The HPV vaccine is given in 2 doses that should begin when a girl is between 9 and 14 years old.

With a comprehensive approach to prevent, screen and treat, we can end cervical cancer as a public health problem within a few generations.

questions.text: You notice a patient in the neurology OPD who has constant, to-and-fro swaying, nodding, and weaving movements of the head and trunk when standing upright. The same is observed even when he sits upright. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Constant, to-and-fro swaying, nodding, and weaving movements of the head and trunk when standing upright as well as while sitting is most likely to be titubation.

In patients with truncal ataxia, swaying and unsteadiness are present while standing. So, the patient would be unable to maintain an upright position. It might be to an extent that there may be a loss of the ability to remain erect even when seated or to even hold the neck and head steady and upright. In severe cases, the disturbance of the standing and sitting balance leads to constant, to-and-fro swaying, nodding, and weaving movements of the head and trunk when the patient is upright. This is known as titubation. The movements of the head in patients with titubation are primarily anteroposterior (yes-yes) at 3 to 4 Hz.

questions.text: Rash in dengue typically occurs during ______.
questions.solution:
Rash in dengue typically occurs during the recovery phase.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus Flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. The extrinsic incubation period that is the time required for the virus to develop inside the mosquito is 8-10 days.

The intrinsic incubation period, the time period between entry of the virus in humans up to the development of the symptoms, is 3–14 days.

Classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. During the febrile phase, dehydration can lead to neurological disturbances and febrile seizures in young children.  

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment is supportive management, with hydration, cold sponging, and paracetamol for fever. Aspirin/ NSAIDS like ibuprofen should be avoided as they can cause vomiting, gastritis, platelet dysfunction and severe bleeding. Fluid and electrolyte replacement and platelet infusion should be done for severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not transmitted by the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Trench fever is not transmitted by sandflies. It is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

Sandflies are involved in the transmission of Kala-azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, and Sandfly fever.

questions.text: Primitive alveoli formation occurs in the fetal lung by _______.
questions.solution:
Primitive alveoli form by 26 weeks in the fetus.

  • 5—16 weeks - Pseudoglandular period
    • Branching has continued to form terminal bronchioles. No respiratory bronchioles or alveoli are present.
  • 16—26 weeks - Canalicular period 
    • Each terminal bronchiole divides into two or more respiratory bronchioles, which in turn divide into three to six alveolar ducts.
  • 26 weeks to birth - Terminal sac period
    • Terminal sacs [primitive alveoli] form and capillaries establish close contact.
  • 8 months to childhood
    • Mature alveoli have well—developed epithelial endothelial [capillary] contacts

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man with emphysema undergoes a pulmonary function test (PFT). Which of the following findings is unlikely?

TLC - Total lung capacity 
FEV - Forced expiratory volume
FVC - Forced vital capacity
RV - Residual volume
questions.solution:
The TLC is increased in emphysema, not decreased.

In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduce, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while it is increased in emphysema. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age with dyspnea being severe very early in the disease, and late-onset cough with scanty sputum. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

Emphysema occurs due to irreversible dilatation and destruction of airspace walls distal to terminal bronchioles. It is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and in smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease-antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress, and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

In emphysema, the upper two-thirds of the lungs are markedly affected. Due to hyperinflation, the lungs become voluminous completely eclipsing the heart anteriorly. 

On microscopy, a thin septum with focal centriacinar fibrosis is seen between abnormally large alveoli. Airspaces with blebs or bullae are seen in advanced disease. There is a loss of elastic tissue in the walls of alveoli in the proximity of bronchioles, due to which there is respiratory collapse during expiration.
 
X-ray shows the presence of hyperinflated lung fields as shown below:

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of griseofulvin?

choices.text: Fungicidal action by inhibiting fungal squalene epoxidase
Fungistatic action by inhibiting fungal squalene epoxidase
Fungicidal action by inhibiting microtubule function
Fungistatic action by inhibiting microtubule function

questions.solution:
Griseofulvin is a fungistatic antifungal agent which disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting microtubule function and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle. 

It is administered orally and its absorption is improved when taken with a fatty meal. It gets deposited in the keratin precursor cells and binds tightly to keratin. Thereby, it provides prolonged resistance to fungal invasion. 

They are only effective against dermatophytes Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is the drug of choice for Tinea capitis and Tinea pedis.

Griseofulvin induces hepatic CYPs and thereby increases the rate of metabolism of warfarin and low-estrogen oral contraceptive agents. Side effects of griseofulvin include headache, gastrointestinal disturbance, and hepatotoxicity.

 

Terbinafine inhibits fungal squalene epoxidase and reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. They are more effective against nail onychomycosis than itraconazole.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Sphenopalatine foramen transmits all of the following structures, except ______.
questions.solution:
The anterior ethmoidal nerve is a branch of the ciliary ganglion. It enters the cranial cavity through the anterior ethmoidal foramen and canal. There it runs forwards in a groove on the upper surface of the cribriform plate beneath the dura mater, and through a slit lateral to the crista galli, descends into the nasal cavity where it gives off the medial and lateral internal nasal branches.

The sphenopalatine foramen serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. It transmits the following structures from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity:

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Nasopalatine nerve
  • Posterior superior nasal nerves (lateral and medial)

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic.
  1. Subcutaneous injection
  2. Injection into brachial plexus
  3. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  4. Injection into lumbar epidural space
questions.solution:
Routes of administration in the descending order of systemic absorption of local anesthetic:

  1. Intercostal nerve blockade 
  2. Injection into the caudal epidural space
  3. Injection into lumbar epidural space
  4. Injection into brachial plexus
  5. Subcutaneous injection

Systemic absorption of local anesthetic is determined by the

  • Site of injection and its tissue blood perfusion
  • Dosage and volume of drug administered
  • Vasoconstrictor agent addition
  • The pharmacologic properties of the agent itself

Exposure to an area of greater vascularity would result in a greater rate and degree of absorption of local anesthetic. The clinical significance of this is that the use of a fixed dose of a local anesthetic agent can be potentially toxic in one area of administration but not in others.

Ex:- Lidocaine without epinephrine for an intercostal nerve block results in average peak venous plasma levels that are sufficiently high to cause symptoms of CNS toxicity. But the same dose of lidocaine when used for a brachial plexus block results in blood levels that are rarely associated with toxicity.

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

The highest blood concentrations are seen following:

  1. Intravenous (intraarterial) injection (maximum)
  2. Intercostal nerve blockade
  3. Paracervical block
  4. Caudal epidural block
  5. Lumbar epidural block
  6. Brachial plexus block
  7. Sciatic block
  8. Subcutaneous injection (minimum)

questions.text: Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in a patient with multifocal atrial tachycardia?

choices.text: Clear isoelectric intervals between P waves

questions.solution:
Irregular rhythm is characteristically associated with MAT, not regular rhythm.

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) is the signature tachycardia of patients with significant pulmonary disease and is often associated with diabetes.

 

Identifying features of Multifocal atrial tachycardia on the ECG are thus:

  • Heart rate >100, typically between 100 and 150 beats/min
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Narrow QRS complex
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies 
  • Variable PR interval
  • Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is directly responsible for the conversion of factor II to IIa in the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
In both the intrinsic and the extrinsic pathways, factor Xa is responsible for the conversion of prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin (factor IIa).

Tissue factor is expressed on the surfaces of the subendothelial cellular components of the vessel wall, such as smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. This tissue factor is exposed to blood when there is vascular damage. This activates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which is as follows:

  • Tissue factor binds with serine protease factor VIIa
  • This complex then activates factor IX to factor IXa
  • Factor IXa then activates factor X to factor Xa
  • Factor Xa can be formed through the actions of either the tissue factor-factor VIIa complex of factor IXa (with factor VIIIa as cofactor)
  • Factor Xa then converts prothrombin to thrombin, which is the pivotal protease of the coagulation cascade.
  • The cofactor essential for this conversion is factor Va.
  • The thrombin then formed converts the soluble plasma fibrinogen to an insoluble fibrin matrix.
  • Thrombin also activates factor XIII, which is the fibrin-stabilizing factor to factor XIIIa. This factor XIIIa forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

questions.text:
The correct sequence of events that occur during the relaxation of skeletal muscles is _______.
  1. Release of Ca2+ from troponin
  2. Pumping back of Ca2+ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  3. Cessation of actin and myosin interaction
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 2->1->3.

Steps in relaxation:

  • Pumping back of Ca2+ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  • Release of Ca2+ from troponin
  • Cessation of actin and myosin interaction

Excitation-contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fiber (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fiber, an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarization.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fiber causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of the sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin filaments on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Tracheal compression is a feature in all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
Tracheal compression is not a feature in carotid sleeper hold.

In carotid sleeper hold, also known as lateral vascular neck restraint, the arm is placed about the neck with the antecubital fossa centered at the midline of the neck. The free hand grips the wrist and the arm is pulled backward, compressing carotid arteries and jugular veins, but not vertebral arteries or trachea. The person loses consciousness in 10 to 15 seconds and regains consciousness within 10 to 20 seconds upon releasing the pressure. Here, the neck structures are not damaged. Death may rarely occur due to catecholamine release or hypoxia which can trigger myocardial infarction or dysrhythmias in patients with ischemic heart disease.

Carotid hold also known as choke hold or bar arm involves placing the forearm straight across the front of the neck. The free hand grips the wrist and pulls it back causing obstruction of the airway and carotids resulting in immediate unconsciousness. Fracture of the hyoid or larynx can occur with greater force. Pressure on the carotid bodies can cause sudden cardiac arrest.

Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

In Bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would the patient have clonal bone marrow plasma cells of 15%, urinary monoclonal protein 700 mg/ 24 h, in the absence of any myeloma defining events or amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Smoldering multiple myeloma refers to an uncommon variant defined by a lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component.

The difference between MGUS, smoldering multiple myeloma, and multiple myeloma is given below:

MGUS Smoldering multiple Myeloma Multiple Myeloma
Asymptomatic Asymptomatic Symptomatic
M protein in serum <3g/dL

M-protein in serum:

  • IgG ≥3 g/dL,
  • IgA >1 g/dL
 M protein in serum and urine
Bone Marrow (BM) plasma cells <10% BM plasma cells 10-60% BM plasma cells >10%
No other organ or tissue impairment No other organ or tissue impairment Related impairment is seen.
(CRAB)

Non-secretory myeloma is characterised by the absence of M protein in the serum or urine. Bone marrow clonal plasmacytosis >10% and myeloma defining symptoms.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants
A. PLASMA CELL NEOPLASMS
 Multiple myeloma (previously plasma cell myeloma)
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L
Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone
Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome 
  • POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes
  • TEMPI syndrome 
  • AESOP syndrome
B. MONOCLONAL IMMUNOGLOBULIN DEPOSITION DISEASES 
Immunoglobulin-related (AL) amyloidosis (previously primary amyloidosis)
  • Systemic AL amyloidosis
  • Localised AL amyloidosis
  • Heavy chain amyloidosis
Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition disease (previously light and heavy chain deposition disease)
  • Light chain deposition disease
  • Heavy chain deposition disease
  • Light and heavy chain deposition disease
C. MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHIES
  • Cold agglutinin disease
  • Monoclonal gammopathy of renal significance
  • IgM and non-IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined signifcance

questions.text: Examination of a patient with a head injury reveals the following. He opens his eyes in response to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, localizes his right hand in response to pain, and extends his left hand in response to pain. Only the right pupil is reactive to light. You would assign scores of _______________________ for his E,V,M and GCS-P scores, respectively.
questions.solution:
The correct scores are 2, 2, 5, and 8 for his E,V,M and GCS-P scores, respectively.

It is calculated as:

  • E - Opens his eyes in response to pain - 2
  • V - Makes incomprehensible sounds - 2 
  • M -
    • Localizes his right hand in response to pain - 5 - Best score is picked
    • Extends his left hand in response to pain - 2
  •  Only the right pupil is reactive to light = -1

Total = 2+2+5-1=8

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Zellweger syndrome is false?

choices.text: Typical age of presentation is 3-5 years
There is defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids
Dysmorphic facial features, hepatomegaly, renal cysts  and hypotonia are typically associated

questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome typically presents in early infancy. In fact, it is the most common peroxisomal disorder to present in early infancy and most infants do not survive past the first 6 months. 

The clinical features of hypotonia, dysmorphic facial features, hepatomegaly, renal cysts and accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormal intermediates of bile acid synthesis, with a deficiency of plasmalogens are suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. It is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with:

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles, markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, etc
  • Profound developmental delay
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Renal cysts
  • Chondrodysplasia punctata- calcific stippling of the patellae, hips, and other epiphysis is seen in the majority of the patients

Biochemical findings will show:

  • accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid
  • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

 

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus, which disappears temporarily with pressure over the left carotid.  Otoscopy reveals a reddish blue mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, suggestive of a glomus tumor. On increasing the ear canal pressure with a Siegel's speculum, which of the following is likely to occur?

choices.text: Patient complains of vertigo and develops nystagmus towards affected ear
Patient complains of vertigo and develops nystagmus towards normal ear
Tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches

questions.solution:
On increasing the ear canal pressure with a Siegel's speculum in a patient with a glomus tumor, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches. This is known as the pulsation sign/ brown sign.

Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IX cranial nerve. 

They are most commonly seen in females between the ages of 40-50 years. They are very slow-growing, thus it may take years before changes in symptoms are appreciated. It follows the rule of 10s - 10% are familial, 10% are multicentric, and 10% are functional (secrete catecholamines).

Depending on the area from which it arises, glomus tumors are classified into two types: 

  • Glomus jugulare, arising from the dome of the jugular bulb
  • Glomus tympanicum, arising from the promontory of the middle ear

The presentation of glomus tumors is as follows:

  • Intratympanic presentation
    • Progressive hearing loss
    • Pulsatile tinnitus is synchronous with pulse and can be stopped by carotid pressure
    • Otoscopy: red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane
    • Rising sign when tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear
    • Pulsation or Brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum the tumor pulsates and blanches. This reverses when pressure is released.
  • Polyp presentation
    • Profuse bleeding
    • Otorrhea if there is a secondary infection
    • Red vascular polyp filling the meatus that bleeds easily
  • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, and pharynx due to IX and X
    • Vocal cord paralysis due to X
    • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles XI
    • Atrophy of half of the tongue XII
  • Audible bruit over the mastoid

They can be diagnosed by CT scan, MRI, four-vessel angiography, brain perfusion and flow studies, embolization, and biopsy. It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

Siegel’s speculum examination in patients with labyrinthine fistula would result in patients complaining of vertigo and developing nystagmus. The quick component of nystagmus would be towards the affected ear in serous labyrinthitis and towards the normal ear in purulent labyrinthitis.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen
Rising sun
Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches
Phelp sign
CT
Loss of carotico-jugular crest

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of the 4th arch, except ______.
questions.solution:
Superior parathyroids and not inferior parathyroids, are derived from the 4th arch. Inferior parathyroids are derived from the 3rd arch.

Each pharyngeal arch is characterized by its own muscular components. The muscular components of each arch have their own cranial nerve. Wherever the muscle cells migrate, they carry their nerve component with them. The neurons of the 5th, 7th, 9th, and 10th cranial sensory ganglia that supply the pharyngeal arch structures are derived from ectodermal placodes (epipharyngeal placodes) and from the neural crest cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the casualty following an RTA. X-Rays taken show the presence of a fracture of the femoral shaft.  Which of the following implants will the orthopedic surgeon use in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given nails used as implants, image 3 shows a Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail), which is used for the treatment of femoral fractures.

It is based on the concept of three-point fixation i.e., at either end and at the isthmus. The eye at the end of the nail is useful while removing it. The Cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

Some common complications of K-nailing:

  • Nail getting stuck
  • Splintering of the cortex while hammering the nail
  • Proximal migration of the nail, leading to bursitis over its protruding end
  • Distal migration of the nail leading to stiffness of the knee
  • Infection

Other options :

Image 1 shows the Smith Petersen nail (SP nail), used for internal fixation of femoral neck fracture.

Smith Petersen nail (SP nail):

It is a cannulated triflanged nail that is used for internal fixation of a fracture of the neck of the femur. Advantages of its triflanged shape:

  • It prevents axial rotation of the fragments
  • It cuts only a little bone to provide good stability.

The nail is cannulated because it is threaded over a guide wire introduced at the correct site under X-ray control. It can be used along with McLaughlin’s plate for the fixation of inter-trochanteric fractures as well.

Image 2 shows Ender’s nail. This is used for internal fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur.

Image 3 shows Talwalkar's square nail. This is used for fractures of forearm bones.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is unlikely to cause struvite stones?
questions.solution:
E. coli never cause struvite stones.

Urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus, break down urea to produce ammonia and CO2. The urine becomes alkaline which promotes the formation of struvite calculi (magnesium ammonium phosphate), which can grow to form a staghorn calculus. 

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A middle-aged man currently on sotalol is to be switched to another antiarrhythmic belonging to the same class. Which of the following drugs could be used?
questions.solution:
Sotalol belongs to class III antiarrhythmics, to which ibutilide belongs as well. Hence, ibutilide can be used.

Sotalol has a high risk of torsades de pointes and hence should be changed to other class III antiarrhythmics with less side effects after regular evaluation.

Option A: Esmolol belongs to class II(beta blockers) antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include bradycardia and hypotension.

Option C: Propafenone belongs to the class IC antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include worsening of heart failure and bronchospasm due to its additional beta blocking action.

Option D: Diltiazem belongs to class IV antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include hypotension, bradycardia, atrioventricular block and constipation.

questions.text:
Match the following respiratory patterns with their corresponding names.
  1. Cheyne-Stokes respiration
  2. Biot’s breathing
  3. Normal breathing
  4. Hyperpnea
questions.solution:
The correct match is A - 4, B - 3, C - 1, D - 2

 The different patterns of respiration are shown below.

 

The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Cheyne-Stokes' breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about heat sterilization is incorrect?

choices.text: Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins
Dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins
Thermal death point is the lowest temperature that kills a bacterium under standard conditions in a given time
Dry heat is more lethal than moist heat

questions.solution:
Moist heat is more lethal than dry heat.

Heat sterilization is an important method for microorganism destruction. Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins.

Dry heat sterilization

Moist heat sterilization

Flaming

Incineration

Hot air oven

Boiling

Pasteurization

Autoclaving

Thermal death point is the lowest temperature that kills a bacterium under standard conditions in a given time. Most bacteria have a thermal death point between 50 and 65°C and most spores between 100 and 120°C.

questions.text: Examination of a patient with specific oculomotor nerve palsy is unlikely to reveal ______.

Limitation of depression of the eye

questions.solution:
Limitation of outward movement of the eye is seen in abducens (sixth cranial ) nerve palsy.
