questions.text: On performing a doppler examination you would observe a monophasic flow in all of the following vessels, except ______.
questions.solution:
The femoral artery has a triphasic blood flow, not monophasic.

The flow velocity waveform through the cardiac cycle depends on the following factors:

  • Cardiac function
  • Blood vessel type
  • State of the distal vascular bed

Elastic arteries like the femoral artery, supplying high-resistance beds, exhibit a pronounced triphasic flow pattern. Rapid systolic upstroke occurs first. This is followed by early diastolic flow reversal because of the combination of arterial wall rebound and high peripheral resistance, resulting in a transient negative doppler component. There may be no forward flow during diastole.

The image given below shows the normal triphasic signal.

In vessels such as the internal carotid, hepatic and renal arteries, a uniphasic pattern is seen with a forward flow throughout the diastole as well.

Monophasic waveform:

questions.text: The type of joint between a tooth and its socket is?
questions.solution:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket. 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis.

Classification of Fibrous joints:

Sutures - Peculiar to the skull. Bones are separated by a layer of membrane-derived connective tissue. Examples include

  • Plane - internasal suture
  • Serrate - interparietal suture
  • Squamous - temporoparietal suture
  • Denticulate - lambdoid suture
  • Schindylesis type, specialized suture in which a ridged bone fits into a groove on a neighboring bone - the cleft between the alae of the vomer receives the rostrum of the sphenoid

Syndesmosis - There is a true fibrous connection between bones. Examples include

  • Connected by interosseous ligament - tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis
  • Connected by a dense fibrous membrane - posterior region of sacroiliac joint

Gomphosis - A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections. Example includes

  • The tooth in its socket

The following image shows the types of fibrous joints:

questions.text:
Match the following: (Consider only the cell indicated by the arrow)
  1. Russel body
  2. Dutcher body
  3. Howell Jolly Body
  4. Dohle body
questions.solution:
The correct match is

  1. - D. Dohle Body
  2. - C. Howell-Jolly body
  3. - A. Russel Body
  4. - B. Dutcher Body

 

Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum seen in neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles. In sepsis or severe inflammatory disorders (Ex: Kawasaki disease), leukocytosis is often accompanied by morphologic changes in the neutrophils, such as toxic granulations, Döhle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Peripheral blood smear preparation with standard Wright-Giemsa stain shows smooth, round basophilic (purple) particles in eosinophilic erythrocytes suggestive of Howell Jolly bodies. Howell-Jolly bodies persist in those with functional hyposplenism or asplenia:

  • Autosplenectomy due to sickle cell anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
  • Radiation therapy
  • Severe hemolytic anemia
  • Splenectomy following trauma

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. Similar inclusion in the intranuclear area is known as Dutcher body.

 

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

choices.text: 48 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy

24 hours after initiation of effective antibiotic therapy

questions.solution:

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

3 weeks.

Influenza

3 days after onset.

Polio

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

Until the swelling subsides.

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease. 

Meningococcal meningitis

Until the first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

Streptococcal pharyngitis

Until the first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

questions.text:
As part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the IOL to be implanted. Which of the following would be used for IOL power calculation by the SRK formula?
  1. Average corneal curvature measured by using keratometry
  2. Axial length of the eyeball measured by using A-scan
  3. Axial length of the eyeball measured by using B-scan
  4. Sagittal diameter of the eyeball measured by using A-scan
  5. Sagittal diameter of the eyeball measured by using B-scan
questions.solution:
Average corneal curvature measured by using keratometry and the axial length of the eyeball measured by using A-scan are used for IOL power calculation by SRK formula (Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff formula).

The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where, 

  • P is the power of IOL
  • A is a constant, which is specific for each lens type
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeter, determined by using the "A" scan ultrasonography
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

questions.text: All of the following are decreased on the administration of epinephrine, except _____.
questions.solution:
Muscle blood flow increases on adrenaline administration. Adrenaline has the following effects on peripheral circulation:

It increases muscle, splanchnic and cerebral blood flow, but decreases total peripheral resistance, cutaneous blood flow, and renal blood flow.

Metabolic parameters are all increased, namely oxygen consumption, blood glucose level, and blood lactic acid. It also causes an eosinopenic response. Respiration and subjective sensations are also increased. Cardiac parameters all show an increase.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with generalized cutaneous eruption to the OPD. On dermoscopy, a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’ appearance is noted. Which of the following agents can be used for the treatment of the child's mother who is currently pregnant?
questions.solution:
The image on the left showing a generalized papulonodular rash and that on the right showing a characteristic burrow resembling a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’ on dermoscopy is suggestive of scabies. All family members, need to be treated simultaneously even if asymptomatic. Of the given options, only precipitated sulfur is safe for use in pregnant females.

Scabies

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mite within the egg
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembling a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patients, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: As per the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs), what is the treatment of choice for pregnant partners of men with urethral discharge?
questions.solution:
As per the syndromic approach to STIs/ RTIs, the treatment of choice for pregnant partners of men with urethral discharge is Cefixime + Erythromycin.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles cause jaw retraction?
questions.solution:
Temporalis causes retraction of the jaw. 

Muscles of mastication: 

Temporalis: It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Medial pterygoid: It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

Lateral pterygoid: It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

Masseter: It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted to the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of mandible/ closing of mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for contrast echocardiography?
questions.solution:
Echocardiography with bubble study or contrast echocardiography is done to look for septal defects. 

Agitated saline contrast provides contrast and enables the detection of right-to-left shunts. Opacification of the left ventricular (LV) cavity by contrast agents developed to traverse the pulmonary vasculature permits improved left ventricular endocardial border detection, thus improving the assessment of left ventricular dimensions and wall motion.

questions.text:
Match the following syndromes with the respective features.
  1. Klinefelter's syndrome
  2. Kallman syndrome
  3. Angelman syndrome
  4. Prader-Willi syndrome
  1. Anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, cryptorchidism, delayed pubertal maturation, and neurological abnormalities.
  2. Gynecomastia, azoospermia, and infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules, a small testis, and XXY karyotype.
  3. Intellectual disability, microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, and inappropriate laughter.
  4. Mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D.

  • Anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, cryptorchidism, delayed pubertal maturation, and neurological abnormalities - Kallman syndrome
  • Gynecomastia, azoospermia, and infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules, a small testis, and XXY karyotype - Klinefelter syndrome
  • Intellectual disability, microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, and inappropriate laughter - Angelman syndrome
  • Mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features - Prader-Willi syndrome

Angelman syndrome is characterized by deletion of the ubiquitin ligase gene (UBE3A) on maternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the paternal chromosomal counterpart. It is characterized by intellectual disability, microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, and inappropriate laughter. Due to inappropriate laughter and ataxia, they are also known as happy puppets.

Prader Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. It is characterized by mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features like

  • Small upturned nose
  • Narrow bifrontal distance
  • Thin upper lip

Klinefelter's syndrome is a genetic disorder that results from a 47, XXY karyotype in phenotypically male patients. They present with gynecomastia, azoospermia, and infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules and a small testis.

Kallman syndrome is associated with a low or absent GnRH that is characterized by anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, cryptorchidism, delayed pubertal maturation, and neurological abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation 

Related Pearl: Indications for various procedures in Infertility treatment

Indications of artificial insemination with husband's semen:

  • Chronic medical disorder
  • Oligospermia after sperm washout
  • Impotency or ejaculatory failure
  • Premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation
  • Hypospadias
  • Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Frozen sperm: If the husband needs to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy or is not available at the time of ovulation
  • X–Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection, in a genetic and chromosomal abnormality
  • HIV positive male or female

Indications for Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT):

  • Sperm count of less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous failed IVF
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona by sperm as seen in IVF

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the frequency of monitoring of GCS is incorrect?

choices.text: Patient with GCS score of 15 at admission should be reassessed every half an hour for 2 hours
Patient with stable GCS score of 15 at admission & upto 2 hours after admission can be monitored every 1 hour once for 4 hours, then 2 hourly thereafter
If the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorates at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly
Patients with GCS <15 at admission should be reassessed every 15 minutes for GCS improvement

questions.solution:
Patients with GCS <15 at admission should be reassessed every 30 minutes.

The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours.
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours.
  • Then 2-hourly thereafter. 

If the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorates at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following features would be seen in a patient with primary biliary cirrhosis but not in a patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis?

choices.text: Development of cirrhosis in advanced disease
Florid granulomatous duct lesions on biopsy

questions.solution:
Florid granulomatous duct lesions on biopsy are seen in primary biliary cirrhosis, not in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis who show characteristic concentric onion-skin fibrosis . 

Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune destructive condition of the small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It is most commonly seen in women who are 40-50 years of age. It is also found in association with other autoimmune diseases such as-

  • Sjogren syndrome
  • Thyroiditis
  • Scleroderma 
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Celiac disease.

Clinical features of PBC include: 

  • Fatigue is out of proportion to liver disease
  • Debilitating pruritis
  • Jaundice
  • Hyperpigmentation of the trunk and arms in areas of repeated scratching
  • Xanthelasma and Xanthoma

Investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes such as GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Biopsy of the liver may confirm the diagnosis and shows a florid duct lesion. This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation. In PBC bile accumulation is seen in peri-portal areas, unlike drug-induced or obstructive cholestasis, where bile is accumulated in the centrizonal areas. Mallory–Denk bodies may also be seen. Cirrhosis usually develops in long-standing diseases.

Ursodeoxycholic acid when started in the early phase of the disease, improves both biochemical and histological features. If there is marked cirrhosis, then liver transplantation is the only definitive treatment. Anti-histamines, narcotic receptor antagonists (naltrexone), and rifampin may be used to manage pruritis. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies aren't seen. Diagnosis is usually done by magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and definitive management is by liver transplantation.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

questions.text: A young male patient has been on antipsychotics for many months. However, recently, he has had focal perioral tremors of the choreoathetoid type. The tongue is spared. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Rabbit syndrome.

Extrapyramidal symptoms like akathasia, acute dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, and Rabbit syndrome are side effects of antipsychotics.

Rabbit syndrome is an antipsychotic-induced rhythmic motion of the mouth/lips resembling the chewing movements of a rabbit.  The movement consists of a vertical-only motion at about 5Hz, with no involvement of the tongue.It occurs months to years after intake of antipsychotics. 

Other options

Options B: Tardive Dyskinesia is involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, trunk, and extremities that occur in patients treated with long-term dopaminergic antagonist medications. It occurs months to years after intake of antipsychotics. 

Option C: Akathisia consists of motor restlessness accompanied by subjective feelings of inner tension and discomfort referable chiefly to the limbs. It occurs within 5-60 days of intake of antipsychotics. 

Option D: Acute dystonia is characterised by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back. It occurs within 1-5 days of intake of antipsychotics. 

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

questions.text: X-Ray of a patient with a suspected pneumothorax reveals a deep sulcus sign. The X-Ray is likely to have been taken in which of the following positions?
questions.solution:
A deep sulcus sign is a supine radiograph finding indicative of pneumothorax.

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent portions of the pleural space.

In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients there may be the presence of deepened costophrenic angles due to hyperinflation of the lungs which can cause a false deep sulcus sign.

The image below shows the deep sulcus sign seen on a chest radiograph:

Pneumothorax is the accumulation of air within the pleural space. It may occur as a result of trauma, surgery, needle aspiration, central line insertion, increased pressure from mechanical ventilation, lung diseases or other conditions.

Other chest radiograph findings in pneumothorax:  

  • Visceral pleural edge appears as a very thin, sharp white line and no lung markings are seen peripheral to this line.
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent when compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless there is the presence of a tension pneumothorax.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.

questions.text: As per the RCOG guidelines, emergency cervical cerclage can be considered up to what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
As per the RCOG guidelines, emergency cervical cerclage can be considered up to 27 weeks of gestation.

Insertion of cerclage as a salvage measure in the case of premature cervical dilatation with exposed fetal membranes in the vagina is known as an emergency cerclage procedure. It can be considered up to 27 weeks of gestation. 

Ultrasound-indicated cerclage is performed on asymptomatic women. The sonographic assessment of the cervix is usually performed between 14 and 24 weeks of gestation by transvaginal sonography.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods of feeding would you employ for each of these neonates under your care?
  1. 26 weeks old neonate
  2. 29 weeks old neonate
  3. 32 weeks old neonate
  1. IV fluids only
  2. IV fluids plus occasional paladai feeds
  3. Orogastric tube feeds only
  4. Orogastric tube feeds plus occasional paladai feeds
  5. Paladai/ spoon/ cup feeding
  6. Breastfeeding
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

  • 26 weeks old neonate - A. IV fluids only
  • 29 weeks old neonate - D. Orogastric tube feeds plus occasional paladai feeds
  • 32 weeks old neonate - E. Paladai/spoon/cup feeding

 

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' own milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo mother care(KMC).

 

Related Pearl: Choice of initial feeding method in LBW infants

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. 

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
 <28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut  Intravenous Fluids
 28-31 weeks

Sucking bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Routine oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
 32-34 weeks The sucking pattern begins to mature. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins  Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
 >34 weeks Mature sucking pattern present. Better coordination between breathing and swallowing  Breastfeeding

questions.text: Which of the following would be the least likely differential to consider in a child with a pansystolic murmur?
questions.solution:
Anemia is typically associated with an ejection systolic murmur, not a pan-systolic murmur. 

VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect), TR (Tricuspid regurgitation), and MR (Mitral regurgitation) can result in a pansystolic murmur. Pansystolic murmurs are always pathological, no matter their intensity. Short, soft systolic murmurs of intensity <grade 3 are often detected during febrile illnesses, after which they disappear. Such murmurs are called innocent murmurs. Before labeling any murmur as innocent, the murmur should be reassessed after an interval. 

Anemia may even result in grade III ejection systolic murmurs in small children. Ejection systolic murmurs are also called mid-systolic murmurs due to them occurring in the middle of the systole, during the ejection phase. They can also be due to Aortic stenosis (AS), Pulmonary stenosis (PS), or Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM).

NADA's criteria for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease:

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur <grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
Gastroduodenoscopy is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulcer disease.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. 

The image below shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval and sharply punched-out defect, and a clean mucosal margin.

Complications of peptic ulcers:

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction.
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. Fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding kangaroo mother care (KMC) is false?

choices.text: Sessions shorter than 1 hour should be avoided
KMC should not be provided while the baby is being fed via orogastric tube or on oxygen therapy
Baby is dressed with cap, socks, nappy and front open sleeveless shirt while on KMC
Length of skin-to- skin contact can be gradually increased up to 24 hours a day with interruption only for changing diapers

questions.solution:
KMC can be provided while the baby is being fed via an orogastric tube or on oxygen therapy.

Kangaroo mother care (KMC) refers to the care of preterm or low birth weight infants by placing the infant in skin-to-skin contact with the mother or any other caregiver. The four components of kangaroo mother care are:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the baby on the mother's chest
  • Exclusive breastfeeding 
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care
  • Support for the mother and her family for taking care of the baby

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birthweight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200-1800g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC. Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased. Sessions shorter than 1 hour should be avoided. Length of skin-to-skin contact can be gradually increased up to 24 hours a day with interruption only for changing diapers. KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Amniotic sac inoculation is used for the primary isolation of _______.
questions.solution:
Amniotic sac inoculation is used for the cultivation of the influenza virus.

The embryonated egg offers several sites for the cultivation of viruses.

  • Inoculation into the allantoic cavity - influenza and some paramyxoviruses.
  • Amniotic sac - isolation of the influenza virus.
  • Allantoic inoculation is used for growing the influenza virus for vaccine production.

Other chick embryo vaccines are rabies vaccine (flurry strain) and yellow fever (17D strain).

These vaccines are contraindicated in children with egg allergy beacuse they are prepared in embryonated egg.

 

Related Pearl: Cultivation of viruses

Animal inoculation:

  • Suckling mice are used for inoculation of coxsackie and arbovirus

Tissue culture: Cell lines

  • Primary cell lines- Rhesus kidney cell line, Human amniotic cell line, Chick embryo fibroblast
  • Secondary cell lines- Human fibroblast cell line, MRC-5, and WI- 38
  • Continuous cell lines- HeLa cell line, HEp-2, KB, Vero

Embryonated egg inoculation:

questions.text: When is the national eye donation fortnight observed?
questions.solution:
August 25 - September 8 is observed as the National Eye donation fortnight.

The relevant statistics are that, just in India, approximately 58 lakh people suffer from corneal blindness in one eye, and 10 lakh people in both eyes. Corneal blindness has been found to be the leading cause of blindness among patients aged less than 50 years in India. The  National Eye Donation Fortnight  is a campaign that aims to create mass public awareness about the importance of eye donation and to motivate people to pledge their eyes for donation after death.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis is to be started on hydroxychloroquine. Which of the following would you advise him prior to starting this drug?
questions.solution:
Prior to starting hydroxychloroquine therapy for rheumatoid arthritis, the patient should be advised to undergo an ocular examination.

Hydroxychloroquine is a disease-modifying drug used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Both chloroquine and its derivative hydroxychloroquine are melanotropic. They get concentrated in the melanin-containing structures of the eye, such as the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and choroid. Significant retinal damage and visual deficits can develop in these patients, sometimes even without any signs on fundus examination. Therefore, baseline visual acuity testing and ocular examination are mandatory before starting hydroxychloroquine for a long duration.

As the retinopathy progresses, it leads to the formation of a bull's eye lesion, as shown in the picture below. It is characterized by pigment deposition in the foveola, surrounded by a ring of depigmented and atrophic RPE. This is further encircled by a hyperpigmented ring.

DMARDs that require tuberculosis screening (option B) include:

  • TNF-α inhibitors such as infliximab, etanercept, and adalimumab
  • JAK inhibitors such as tofacitinib and baricitinib
  • Interleukin-6 inhibitors such as tocilizumab
  • Anakinra
  • Abatacept

DMARDs that require evaluation for viral hepatitis include:

  • Leflunomide 
  • Methotrexate
  • Rituximab

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding maternal mirror syndrome is false?

choices.text: Prompt delivery is followed by resolution of maternal edema and other findings
Also called as triple edema as mother, fetus and the placenta are all edematous
The etiology of the hydrops is not related to development of mirror syndrome
Considered a severe form of eclampsia

questions.solution:
Maternal Mirror Syndrome may be considered a severe form of preeclampsia, not eclampsia. Even this hypothesis is disputed. 

An association between fetal hydrops and the development of maternal edema in which the fetus mirrors the mother. Also, triple edema because the fetus, mother, and placenta all became edematous. Mirror syndrome may be considered a form of severe preeclampsia as the clinical features in women with Mirror syndrome are similar to preeclampsia:

  • Edema
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Liver enzyme elevation
  • Headache and visual disturbances

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Bain circuit?

choices.text: Fresh gas enters the circuit near the patient end
Adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve is located away from the patient
It does not have a reservoir bag

questions.solution:
Bain circuit has a reservoir bag. Ayre's T-piece lacks a reservoir bag.

Components of Mapleson's system are:

  • Breathing tube
  • Fresh gas inlet
  • Adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve 
  • Reservoir bag

 

Bain's circuit with its components, fresh gas inlet, corrugated breathing tubes, APL valve, and reservoir bag. The central fresh gas tubing enters the outer corrugated tube near the reservoir bag, but the fresh gas empties into the circuit at the patient’s end.

Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: Histopathological examination would reveal which of the following characteristic findings in serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are the histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary.

They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions:

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Meningioma

The image below shows Psammoma body.

 

Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland-like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumours.

 

A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. It is most often seen in children and young women. It usually presents as abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass. 

Grossly, the yolk-sac tumor appears yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and forms a solid mass. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

 

Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in Krukenberg tumor.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Which of the following structures involved in the baroreceptor reflex pathway secrete the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA?
questions.solution:
CVLM - Caudal ventrolateral medulla secrete the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA.

 

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate NTS  by releasing glutamate. The NTS in turn activates CVLM by releasing glutamate. The CVLM on activation releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the RVLM. The RVLM is the major excitatory source to the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure. The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons thus causing bradycardia.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels.

The receptors of arterial circulation include:

  • Carotid sinus - present in the adventitia of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid. Afferent nerve innervation is by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve called the carotid sinus nerve.
  • Aortic arch - present in the adventitia of the walls of the arch of aorta. Afferent innervation is by the vagus nerve called the aortic depressor nerve.

The receptors of low-pressure system/ cardiopulmonary receptors are:

  • Atrial receptors - are present in the walls of right and left atria near the opening of the superior and inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins.
  • Pulmonary circulation receptors.

Baroreceptors are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true statements regarding topical hemostatic agents?
  1. Safe to use intravascularly
  2. Can be used for leakage prevention from colonic anastomoses 
  3. Can be used on cut edges of bone
  4. Can be used on cut edges of solid organs
  5. Can be used to close air leaks following lung resection
questions.solution:
Topical hemostatic agents should not be used intravascularly as they cause thrombosis.

Indications for use — Topical hemostatic agents are primarily used for diffuse bleeding from:

  • Peritoneal or pleural surfaces
  • Cut surfaces of solid organs 
  • Cut edges of bone
  • Bleeding near nerves
  • Bleeding near vital structures at risk for cautery-induced injury
  • Bleeding from vascular structures or grafts due to suture holes
  • Nasal structures as nasal packing
  • Dental extraction sites
  • Air leak following lung resection 
  • Eardrum perforation
  • Endoscopic control of gastrointestinal bleeding 
  • Leakage prevention from colonic anastomoses 

Contraindications:

  • Topical hemostatic agents should not be used intravascularly as they cause thrombosis.
  • Should not be used in confined spaces where the expansion of the product could lead to compression.

questions.text: Fracture of the tibia caused by avulsion due to the anterior tibiofibular ligament is known as ____.
questions.solution:
The avulsion fracture of the tibia caused by the anterior tibiofibular ligament is known as the Tillaux fracture.

In children and adolescents, this fragment is usually the lateral part of the tibial epiphysis and would thus be considered as a Salter-Harris type 3 fracture. 

Pilon fracture refers to a comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal tibia. These fractures are most often due to high-energy trauma such as a motor vehicle accident or a fall from a height. 

The below image shows Pilon fracture. 

An aviator's fracture is a coronal-plane fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle. It is the second most common talar fracture, after talar dome fractures.

Comminuted fracture of the lateral condyle of the tibia is known as a bumper fracture.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding neonatal jaundice is true?
  1. Exclusively breastfed infants have a different pattern of physiological jaundice as compared to artificially fed babies
  2. Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding
  3. Breast milk jaundice occurs due to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  4. Breastfeeding should be stopped to establish the diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice
  5. Breastfeeding should not be stopped for treatment of breastmilk jaundice
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 2, and 5.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Exclusively breastfed infants have a different pattern of physiological jaundice as compared to artificially fed babies. (Statement 1)
  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. 
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice) (Statement 2)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. (Statement 3)
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week.
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases. (Statement 4)
  • Breastfeeding is not stopped for the treatment of breast milk jaundice. (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on, coughing and sneezing. What is the grade as per the genuine stress incontinence scale?
questions.solution:
A patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing has stress incontinence of grade I. 

In stress incontinence, there is an involuntary leakage of urine whenever there is increased intraabdominal pressure (e.g., sneezing, coughing, Valsalva manoeuvre). It is because of a lack of detrusor muscle contraction.

Risk factors include:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation
  • Chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress - coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress - walking and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress - standing.

Investigations include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are required before surgery and not required before conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, alpha agonists, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in the classification of acute kidney injury according to the AKIN criteria?

choices.text: Extent of increase of creatinine above baseline

questions.solution:
The estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is not a component of the AKIN criteria. The components are:

  • Adults - serum creatinine and urine output

The following criteria are used for the staging of acute kidney injury (AKI):

  • RIFLE criteria (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage)
  • AKIN (AKI Network) classification
  • KDIGO (Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes) classification
   

Risk (RIFLE)

Stage 1 (AKIN/KDIGO)

Injury (RIFLE)

Stage 2 (AKIN/KDIGO)

Failure (RIFLE)

Stage 3 (AKIN/KDIGO)

 Loss (RIFLE) End stage (RIFLE)
RIFLE Creatinine rise from baseline 1.5 times 2 times 3 times (or) ↑ by 0.5 – 4 mg/dl (or) initiating RRT Need for RRT > 4 wks Need for RRT > 3 mo
  Urine output (ml/kg/h) < 0.5 for 6-12 hours < 0.5 for 12-24 hours < 0.3 for >24h (or) anuria >12h    
AKIN Creatinine rise from baseline ≧0.3 mg/dl (or) 150-200% rise 200-300% rise 300% (or) ↑ by 0.5 – 4 mg/dl (or) initiating RRT – –
  Urine output < 0.5 for 6-12 hours < 0.5 for 12-24 hours < 0.3 for >24h (or) anuria >12h – –
KDIGO Creatinine rise from baseline ≧0.3 mg/dl (or)1.5-1.9 times 2.0-2.9 times 3.0 times (or) ↑ by 0.3 – 4 mg/dl (or) initiating RRT – –
  Urine output < 0.5 for 6-12 hours < 0.5 for 12-24 hours < 0.3 for >24h (or) anuria >12h – –

S.Cr - serum creatinine

Note: eGFR is used in the pediatric KDIGO criteria.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features would be seen in a patient with right medial medullary syndrome?
  1. Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion 
  2. Contralateral tongue weakness with deviation away from the lesion 
  3. Ipsilateral touch and proprioceptive loss
  4. Contralateral touch and proprioceptive loss
  5. Contralateral hemiparesis due to pyramidal tract involvement.
questions.solution:
The characteristic triad of the medial medullary syndrome includes:

  • Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion due to the lower motor neuron lesion of CN XII
  • Contralateral touch and proprioceptive loss due to medial lemniscus involvement
  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to pyramidal tract involvement.

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature would be seen, in a lesion of the ventrolateral spinothalamic tract. Medial medullary syndrome spares the lateral spinothalamic tract, hence contralateral pain and temperature sensations are preserved.

questions.text: All of the following structures form a boundary of the myopectineal orifice of Fruchaud, except _____.

choices.text: Internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle

questions.solution:
The inguinal ligament runs through the myopectineal orifice and does not form its boundary. It divides the myopectineal orifice into two regions: the suprainguinal region and the subinguinal region.

The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel that all groin hernias occur. It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

Below is the image of the myopectineal orifice.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements about isosorbide dinitrate is false?

choices.text: Prophylactic dose of 2.5-5 mg sublingually can be taken 15 minutes prior to performing activities likely to cause angina
For angina treatment, 2.5-5 mg sublingually may be repeated q5-10min but not to exceed 3 doses in 15-30 minutes
Inability to relieve chest pain after 3 doses may signal acute MI necessitating emergency management
Any brand can be interchanged as formulations are bioequivalent

questions.solution:
Do not change brands unintentionally as the available formulations are not all bioequivalent.

A prophylactic dose of 2.5-5 mg sublingually can be taken 15 minutes prior to performing activities likely to cause angina.

For angina treatment, 2.5-5 mg sublingually may be repeated q5-10min but not to exceed 3 doses in 15-30 minutes. Inability to relieve chest pain after 3 doses may signal acute MI necessitating emergency management.

Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate/ ISDN act by increasing the concentration of the second messenger cGMP. They are used to relieve angina and cause vasodilation.

questions.text: While interpreting the blood reports of a pregnant female, you would consider all of the following as normal, except ______.

choices.text: Same clotting time as prior to pregnancy

questions.solution:
Reticulocyte count is increased in pregnancy, not decreased.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. This is in order to control bleeding and help in hemostasis after placental separation. Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased, except factors 11 and 13. The levels return to normal within 2 weeks of delivery. But clotting time is unaffected.
  • Anticoagulants protein C, protein S, and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • Fibrinogen levels are also increased by 50%.
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to relative hemodilution (relatively higher increase in plasma volume as compared to the increase in RBC mass).
  • ESR is raised due to an increase in fibrinogen and globulin levels.
  • Because of a marked fall in albumin level and only a slight rise of globulin, the normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1.
  • Platelet counts remain the same or fall by a small amount (15%). The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: All of the following antioxidants primarily function by reducing the rate of chain initiation, except _______.
questions.solution:
Superoxide dismutase acts in the aqueous phase to trap superoxide free radicals and hence is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Urate, and vitamin E act in the lipid phase to trap free radicals and are also considered chain-breaking antioxidants. 

Antioxidants fall into two classes:

  • Preventive antioxidants reduce the rate of chain initiation of lipid peroxidation.
  • Chain-breaking antioxidants interfere with the chain propagation phase of lipid peroxidation.

Preventive antioxidants include:

  • Catalase 
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Selenium - It is an essential component of glutathione peroxidase and regulates its activity
  • Chelators of metal ions such as ethylenediaminetetraacetate (EDTA) and diethylenetriaminepentaacetate (DTPA).

Related Pearl: Types of Antioxidants

Preventive Antioxidants

Chain-breaking Antioxidants
  • Catalase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Chelator of metal Ions-Ceruloplasmin & Transferrin
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Urate
  • Vitamin E
  • Polyphenols

questions.text: Which of the following structures and their location in the middle ear is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Canal for facial nerve - medial wall

questions.solution:
The canal for tensor tympani is located on the anterior wall, not on the roof.

The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoideum.

The image below shows the tegmen tympani.

The middle ear has a roof, floor, and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

  • Roof: Formed by tegmen tympani bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone
  • Anterior wall: Structures related are
    • Eustachian tube
    • Canal of tensor tympani
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall: It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is present above the pyramid. The posterior sinus, also known as the facial recess, is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the VII nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani, and above by the fossa incudis. Intact canal wall techniques use this for middle ear access.
  • Medial wall: It is formed by the labyrinth and it presents as a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to:
    • Oval window
    • round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of the facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called the scutum.

The following image shows the relations of middle ear:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Bohler Braun Splint?

choices.text: The proximal pulley prevents foot drop.
The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the ipsilateral hip joint.
The second pulley is to apply traction in the line of the femur.
It can also be used for the fractured shaft of the tibia and fibula.

questions.solution:
The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the legs.

Bohler Braun splint: This refers to Bohler’s modification of the Braun splint. It consists of a heavy metal frame with four pulleys. The respective functions of the pulleys are:

  1. The proximal pulley prevents foot drop.
  2. The second pulley is to apply traction in the line of the femur.
  3. The third pulley is to apply traction in the line of the supracondylar area of the femur.
  4. The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the legs.

 

It is used for the treatment of fracture shaft femur and supracondylar fractures of the femur. It can also be used for the fractured shaft of the tibia and fibula.

questions.text:
During the examination of a patient, you notice that he has an abnormal second heart sound. A careful evaluation reveals that his aortic component is significantly delayed compared to his pulmonary component. Which of the following conditions should you consider as part of his differential diagnosis?
  1. VSD
  2. Constrictive Pericarditis
  3. AR
  4. LBBB
  5. AS
  6. MR
questions.solution:
The A2 occurs early, not delayed, in conditions like VSD, mitral regurgitation, and constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, the aortic component is heard prior to the pulmonary component of S2 i.e. as A2-P2. Both components are superimposed on each other during the expiratory phase of quiet breathing. Thus only a single second sound is heard. But, during inspiration, the aortic component comes earlier and the pulmonary component is delayed, resulting in a split where A2 precedes the P2. Usually, the aortic component is louder than the pulmonary component, except in young infants.

Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting refers to the situation when P2 is heard before A2. A2 is delayed in the following conditions, which prolong the left ventricular ejection:

  1. Aortic valvar or subvalvar stenosis
  2. Patent ductus arteriosus with large left to right shunt
  3. AR
  4. Left Bundle Branch Block
  5. Left ventricular failure.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for evaluation of the proximal biliary tree in a patient?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography) is the gold standard for visualisation of biliary tree in a patient.

MRCP stands for Magnetic Resonance Cholangio Pancreaticography. It is a non-invasive diagnostic procedure using MRI. Therapeutic procedures cannot be done. 

ERCP is the next line of management for this patient. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. A side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be both therapeutic and diagnostic.

If an endoscope is visible in the radiological image it is always an ERCP, whereas in MRCP there will be no endoscope. 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text:
Which of the following would be seen in a patient with complete androgen insensitivity?
  1. Normal pubic and axillary hair
  2. 46 XX karyotype
  3. Very Low testosterone levels
  4. Absent uterus
  5. Normal breasts
questions.solution:
Absent uterus and normal breasts would be seen in patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome. 

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-Linked Recessive condition in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. The karyotype is 46, XY and affected individuals have normal male levels of testosterone, but the lack of receptor response to testosterone is responsible for the manifestations. Hence, gonad is testis and the uterus is absent. The pubic and axillary hair are sparse since they are androgen dependent. But, breast development is normal.
