questions.text: Any of the following drugs may be used as part of the regimen for PrEP (Pre Exposure Prophylaxis) for HIV prevention as per the CDC, except _____.
questions.solution:
Lamivudine is recommended for use in Post-Exposure prophylaxis, not in Pre-Exposure prophylaxis.

PrEP/ Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis is the use of antiretroviral medication to prevent HIV infection. PrEP is used by people without HIV who may be exposed to HIV through sex or injection drug use. The drugs recommended by the CDC guidelines are:

  1. Emtricitabine (F) 200 mg in combination with tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) 300 mg (F/TDF)
  2. Emtricitabine (F) 200 mg in combination with tenofovir alafenamide (TAF) 25 mg (F/TAF).
  3. Cabotegravir (CAB) 600 mg injection.

 

This is in contrast to Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP), which should be offered and initiated as early as possible, to all individuals with exposure that has potential for HIV transmission. It should be initiated ideally within 2 hours but certainly within 72 hours.

The exposure that may need occupational PEP are:

  • Parenteral or mucous membrane exposure like splashes to the eye, nose, oral cavity
  • Body fluids that may pose a risk of HIV infection:
    • Blood
    • Blood-stained saliva
    • Breast-milk
    • Genital secretions
    • CSF
    • Amniotic fluid
    • Rectal, peritoneal, synovial, pericardial ,and pleural fluid

The exposures that do not require PEP include:

  • The exposed individual is already positive for HIV
  • The source individual was established to be negative for HIV
  • Body fluids that don't pose a significant risk like tears, non-blood stained saliva, urine, and sweat

All individuals potentially exposed to HIV should undergo HIV testing 3 months following exposure. An enhanced adherence counseling must be given to all individuals initiating HIV PEP. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir

questions.text: You notice the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below. Which of the following steps is best suited in his management?

choices.text: Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization
Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium
Continue monitoring as the capnogram is normal

questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing. Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems. Hence, replacing the soda lime would be the best step in this situation.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A - Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization would benefit a patient with esophageal intubation. It shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero. Also, breath sounds in the epigastrium are a sign of oesophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium. 

Option B- Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium would be indicated in patients with malignant hyperthermia. A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity would normally be accompanying features. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: What is the minimum dose of radiation exposure that may result in hematopoietic acute radiation syndrome?
questions.solution:
The hematopoietic system is the first organ system that demonstrates injury at doses between 0.7-10 Gy (70-1000 rads). The prodromal phase occurs within hours to days from exposure and is followed by a latent phase for 1-3 weeks.

Radiation damages the bone marrow cells and the circulating hematopoietic cells- mainly the lymphocytes. Granulocytes, platelets, and erythrocytes are also affected, erythrocytes being the least affected as they lack nuclei.

Cell counts increase immediately after the exposure because they are markers of inflammation. However, they later decline and reach an all-time low within 30 days of the injury. Since there is preferential destruction of lymphocytes, the peripheral lymphocyte count is currently the best marker to grade the extent of the injury.

The survival rate of hematopoietic syndrome decreases with increasing doses, but aggressive management with blood products and growth factors makes survival possible.

Syndrome    Dose* Prodromal Stage  Latent Stage Manifest Illness Stage Recovery
Hematopoietic (Bone marrow)  >0.7 Gy (>70 rads) (mild symptoms may occur as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
  • Onset occurs 1 hour to 2 days after exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to days.  

Stem cells in bone marrow are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.

Stage lasts 1 to 6 weeks. 

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, fever, and malaise.
  • Drop in all blood cell counts occurs for several weeks.
  • Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage.
  • Survival decreases with increasing dose.
  • Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure.  

In most cases, bone marrow cells will begin to repopulate the marrow.

  • There should be full recovery for a large percentage of individuals from a few weeks up to two years after exposure.
  • Death may occur in some individuals at 1.2 Gy (120 rads).
  • The LD50/60† is about 2.5 to 5 Gy (250 to 500 rads). 
Gastrointestinal (GI) >10 Gy (>1000 rads) (some symptoms may occur as low as 6 Gy or 600 rads)

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, severe nausea, vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea.
  • Onset occurs within a few hours after exposure.
  • Stage lasts about 2 days.

Stem cells in bone marrow and cells lining GI tract are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.

Stage lasts less than 1 week.

Symptoms are

  • malaise, anorexia, severe diarrhea, fever, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death is due to infection, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death occurs within 2 weeks of exposure.
 The LD100 is about 10 Gy (1000 rads).
Cardiovascular (CV)/ Central Nervous System (CNS) >50 Gy (5000 rads) (some symptoms may occur as low as 20 Gy or 2000 rads)

Symptoms are

  • extreme nervousness and confusion; severe nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea; loss of consciousness; and burning sensations of the skin.
  • Onset occurs within minutes of exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to hours.

Patient may return to partial functionality.

Stage may last for hours but often is less.

Symptoms are

  • return of watery diarrhea, convulsions, and coma.
  • Onset occurs 5 to 6 hours after exposure.
  • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure.
 No recovery is expected.

questions.text: As per the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation on the LCG should begin at _____.
questions.solution:
As per the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation on the LCG should begin at 5 cm of dilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the lab criteria for diagnosis of APLA syndrome?
questions.solution:
Raised aPTT is not a lab criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before 10 weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), also referred to as a recurrent miscarriage or habitual abortion, is historically defined as 3 consecutive pregnancy losses before 20 weeks from the last menstrual period. 

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: Secretion of which of the following hormones peaks in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Secretion of relaxin peaks in the first trimester.

Hormones whose secretion peaks in the first trimester are hCG and relaxin.

Hormones whose secretion peaks at term are:

  • hCS
  • Estriol
  • Estradiol
  • Progesterone
  • Prolactin

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in a patient in the early stages of retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, impaired central vision is least likely to be seen in patients with retinitis pigmentosa. Even patients with advanced disease often have a small island of residual central vision, demonstrable by perimetry. Only in very advanced cases, central vision impairment is seen.

Nyctalopia/ impaired dark adaptation is often the presenting symptom in retinitis pigmentosa. Also, contrast sensitivity is often affected at an earlier stage, usually earlier than visual acuity.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Occular examination will reveal normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision may be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy will show bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There will be severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataract, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer-controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: What is the primary action of the muscle attached in the marked area on the upper end of the femur?
questions.solution:
The image shows femur, and the structure marked is the intertrochanteric crest, to which the quadratus femoris muscle is attached. It produces lateral rotation of the thigh.

Quadratus femoris is a flat, quadrilateral muscle lying between the gemellus inferior and the upper margin of adductor magnus. It is separated from the adductor magnus by the transverse branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery. It arises from the upper part of the external aspect of the ischial tuberosity and inserts onto a small tubercle a little above the middle of the intertrochanteric crest of the femur and into the bone for a short distance below. It may be absent.

Vascular supply: Branches from the inferior gluteal artery and the medial circumflex femoral artery.

Innervation: It is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris, L5, and S1.

Actions: It produces lateral rotation of the thigh. Lateral rotation is produced by gluteus maximus, obturator internus, superior and inferior gemelli, quadratus femoris and piriformis, and it is assisted by obturator externus and sartorius. Adduction is produced by adductors longus, brevis and magnus and by gracilis. Assisted by pectineus, quadratus femoris and the inferior fibres of gluteus maximus. 

Testing: The short rotators cannot be tested individually, but the lateral rotation of the extended hip and abduction of the flexed hip against resistance test them as a group. 

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

questions.text: The descending order of incidence of polyps in the case of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome is:
questions.solution:
The descending order of incidence of polyps in the case of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome is Small intestine > Colon > Stomach.

Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract and melanosis of the mouth and the lips. 

Clinical features:

  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract.
  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, perianal skin, and digits.
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract, with cancers reported throughout the intestinal tract, from the stomach to the rectum.
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Management:

  • Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp.
  • If surgery is done for these indications, attempts should be made to remove as much polyps as possible. 
  • Regular screening with endoscopic studies should be done due to the increased risk of malignancies.
  • Screening of other malignancies like breast and cervix are also important.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their corresponding tympanometry curves.
  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Retracted tympanic membrane
  3. CSOM
  4. Ossicular discontinuity
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. Otosclerosis - Type As curve
  2. Retracted tympanic membrane - Type C curve
  3. CSOM - Type B curve
  4. Ossicular discontinuity - Type Ad curve

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more of sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are obtained. They are as follows:

questions.text: On performing the ABCD2 scoring for a patient with a transient ischemic attack, the maximum possible score of 7 is obtained. What is the interpretation?

choices.text: The patient has a 12% 3 month rate of stroke
The patient has a 22% 3 month rate of stroke
The patient has a 5% 3 month rate of stroke
The patient has a 55% 3 month rate of stroke

questions.solution:
Since the patient has a score of 7 in the ABCD2 score, he has a 22% 3-month rate of stroke, indicating a high risk.

ABCD2 Score is used for stroke risk assessment following a transient ischemic attack.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about CAMP and reverse CAMP tests?

choices.text: Reverse CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae; CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Staphylococcus aureus; CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Staphylococcus aureus; CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens; CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.solution:
CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae; reverse CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

CAMP test: 

The Christie-Atkins-Munch-Peterson (CAMP) test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor, which causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus.

When Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to Staphylococcus aureus grown on blood agar, a characteristic arrowhead zone of hemolysis is seen. The group B streptococci hydrolyze sodium hippurate and give a positive CAMP test.

Reverse CAMP test:

The test is called the reverse CAMP test because the CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the differentiation of C. perfringens from other Clostridium species.

  1. A CAMP-positive group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is streaked in the center of sheep blood agar, and Clostridium perfringens is streaked perpendicular to it.
  2. Following incubation at 37°C for 24-48 hours in anaerobic conditions, an arrowhead zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards Streptococcus agalactiae is seen.
  3. This is because the alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis.

questions.text: A biochemist performed electrophoresis on lipoproteins during a study and has obtained results as shown below. The marked lipoprotein which has hardly moved from the origin is likely to be _______.
questions.solution:
The marked lipoprotein which has hardly moved towards the anode during electrophoresis is likely to be chylomicron.

Chylomicron particles have the lowest density and the largest size. They contain the highest percentage of lipids and the lowest percentage of protein.

questions.text: During your labor postings, you notice the resident preferred the mediolateral episiotomy instead of the midline episiotomy. All of the following are true statements about mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy, except that _______.
questions.solution:
All of the following are true statements about the advantages of mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy except that blood loss is lesser (Option B). Mediolateral episiotomy is associated with a greater amount of blood loss than midline episiotomy.

Episiotomy: Surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy. 

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is the least Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with wet age-related macular degeneration is being administered ranibizumab intravitreally. All of the following are known side effects of the drug, except _______.
questions.solution:
Ranibizumab is associated with a raise in IOP, not a fall.

Ranibizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against VEGF-A (vascular endothelial growth factor-A). Ranibizumab is indicated in wet age-related macular degeneration and is used intravitreally where it inhibits VEGF-A induced ocular neovascularization.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Nikolsky's sign positive?
questions.solution:
Nikolsky's sign is positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Nikolsky's sign refers to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis by applying firm tangential sliding pressure, thereby producing erosion. It is seen in conditions that produce intraepidermal blisters. Hence it is negative in subepidermal bullous conditions like bullous pemphigoid and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

Nikolsky sign is negative in:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Pseudo Nikolsky's sign is positive for Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, some burn cases, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma. Here, the underlying pathophysiology is necrosis and not acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign.

questions.text:
An RBSK medical officer who has clear reason to suspect that a child is being sexually abused fails to report it to the appropriate authorities. What is the punishment for the same?

RBSK - Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram

choices.text: Penal erasure from state medical council registry
Imprisonment of up to six months and/or fine
Imprisonment of up to six years and/or fine
Warning notice from state medical council registry

questions.solution:
All suspected sexual offences must be reported to the police as a rule. Failure to comply with this mandatory provision of the POCSO Act can attract imprisonment for up to 6 months or a fine or both. 

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 considers all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years as children and protects them from sexual abuse. The offences and respective punishments in the provisions of this act are as follows -

Offence Punishment If aggravated
1. Penetrative sexual assault Imprisonment for 10 or more years; May extend for life with a fine. Imprisonment for 20 years or more; May extend for life with a fine, or with death.
2. Sexual assault without penetration Imprisonment for ≥ 3-5 years and fine Imprisonment for ≥ 5-7 years and fine
3. Sexual harassment Imprisonment for 3 years and fine  
4. Child pornography

Imprisonment for 5 years and fine; 

A subsequent conviction is liable to 7 years of imprisonment and a fine.

  

 

Penal erasure is done for serious professional misconduct. It is also referred to as the professional death sentence. It deprives the practitioner of all the privileges of a registered practitioner. Serious Professional Misconduct/ Infamous Conduct in professional respect is any conduct of the doctor that might reasonably be regarded as disgraceful or dishonourable.

questions.text: A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is a false statement regarding her management?

choices.text: No need to advise to abstain from intercourse or to use a condom during the period of therapy, if simultaneously treated
Metronidazole 400 mg by mouth three times a day for 5 days for both partners
Alternate regimen that can be used is 2 g metronidazole for 1 day only
Metronidazole should be avoided in first trimester of pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomoniasis. The patient and partner should be advised to abstain from intercourse or use a condom during the period of therapy even if treated simultaneously.

Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots known as the strawberry cervix is typically seen in trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in color, and frothy. It may be associated with vaginal irritation, dysuria, and increased frequency. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination. Metronidazole is used as the drug of choice in its treatment.

The image below shows strawberry cervix seen in trichomoniasis.

Management:

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose (or 400 mg 3 times/day for 5 days orally ) is the standard treatment. It should be taken at night, after meals to avoid vomiting. If this too causes vomiting, or in resistant cases consider the use of alternative drugs.
  • The alternative regimen includes tinidazole 2g as a single dose or secnidazole in a single dose of 2g. Single-dose therapy ensures better compliance.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Hyperpolarization in response to a stimulus is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization.

In most sensory receptors: Arrival of stimulus → Ion channels are opened up allowing current to flow => depolarisation of the receptor.

In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer image below) are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment, resulting in hyperpolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding the effect of potassium on glucose tolerance?

choices.text: K+ levels have no significant bearing on the glucose tolerance of the body
Use of thiazide diuretics causes improved glucose tolerance
K+ depletion results in increased insulin secretion
K+ repletion, when low, would help  restore the glucose tolerance curves to normal

questions.solution:
K+ repletion would help restore the glucose tolerance curves to normal.

Effects of K+ on glucose tolerance

  • K+ depletion decreases insulin secretion.
    •  Ex:-
      • Patients with primary hyperaldosteronism, develop diabetic glucose tolerance curves.
      • Thiazide diuretics cause loss of K+ as well as Na+ in the urine and hence cause decreased glucose tolerance and make diabetes worse. The apparent reason for this effect is mainly because of their K+-depleting effects, but some of them also cause pancreatic islet cell damage. Hence, potassium-sparing diuretics should be substituted in diabetic patients who need such treatment.
  • K+ repletion restores the glucose tolerance curves back to normal.

questions.text: Transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junctions include all, except ______.
questions.solution:
Hemidesmosomes attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are not part of the transmembrane proteins that contribute to tight junction formation. They are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments. However, unlike desmosomes, they contain integrins rather than cadherins.

Three families of transmembrane proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions/ zonula occludens:

  1. Occludin
  2. Junctional adhesion molecule
  3. Claudins

Zonula occludens are also known as tight junctions and characteristically surround the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. Also important to the endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation. They are made up of ridges- half from one cell and half from another cell- which adhere so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signaling molecules between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Other intercellular junctions -

Gap junctions:

The gap between the two cells is about 4nm. These junctions are formed by units called connexons, which are present in the membrane of each cell. Each connexon is made up of six protein subunits called connexions. They permit substances to pass between the cells, without entering the ECF.

The pore diameter is around 0.8 to 1.4  nm, which permits the passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes which weigh up to 1000 Da. They also permit rapid propagation of electrical activity from cell to cell and the exchange of various chemical messengers and intracellular signalling molecules.

Adherent junctions:

  • Adherent junction or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens.
  • It contains cadherins.

The image below shows adherent junctions.

questions.text: The characteristic feature of pyroptosis is:

choices.text: Excessive intracellular levels of reactive oxygen species

questions.solution:
The characteristic feature of pyroptosis is the release of cytokine interleukin-1.

Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

  • There is cellular swelling
  • There is loss of cell membrane integrity 
  • It is associated with inflammation 
  • Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent pathway of cell death that is induced by lipid peroxidation. It is triggered by an increase in membrane lipid peroxidation in response to the following signals:

  • Excessive intracellular levels of iron
  • Reactive oxygen species (ROS)

This leads to a loss of selective permeability of the plasma membrane, which ultimately leads to cell death. Unlike necrosis, the process is regulated by specific signals and can, therefore, be prevented by reducing iron levels.

Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies including:

  • Cancer
  • Neurodegenerative diseases
  • Stroke
